rule_text_en: Use the present continuous for something happening now (around the moment of speaking).
rule_text_uk: Вживай Present Continuous для дії, що відбувається зараз (приблизно в момент мовлення).
examples: I'm talking to you right now.
She is driving home at the moment.
We are waiting outside.

rule_text_en: Form: am/is/are + verb-ing. Use the short forms I'm, he's, we're, etc.
rule_text_uk: Форма: am/is/are + дієслово з -ing. Використовуй скорочення I'm, he's, we're тощо.
examples: She's listening to a podcast.
They're having lunch.
I'm not working today.

rule_text_en: Negative: am/is/are not + -ing. Questions: Am/Is/Are + subject + -ing?
rule_text_uk: Заперечення: am/is/are not + -ing. Питання: Am/Is/Are + підмет + -ing?
examples: He isn't sleeping.
Are you coming with us?
What are they doing?

rule_text_en: Spelling: usually add -ing (work→working); sometimes drop final -e (make→making) or double a consonant (sit→sitting).
rule_text_uk: Правопис: зазвичай додаємо -ing (work→working); інколи прибираємо кінцеве -e (make→making) або подвоюємо приголосну (sit→sitting).
examples: run → running
lie → lying
write → writing

rule_text_en: Use the present simple for habits, repeated actions, and things that are generally true.
rule_text_uk: Вживай Present Simple для звичок, регулярних дій і загальних фактів.
examples: I go to the gym on Mondays.
Water boils at 100°C.
She works in a café.

rule_text_en: Questions: do/does + subject + base verb (Do you work? Does he work?).
rule_text_uk: Питання: do/does + підмет + базова форма (Do you work? Does he work?).
examples: Do you like tea?
Does your brother drive?
Where do they live?

rule_text_en: Negative: don't/doesn't + base verb (I don't work; he doesn't work).
rule_text_uk: Заперечення: don't/doesn't + базова форма (I don't work; he doesn't work).
examples: I don't eat meat.
She doesn't speak French.
They don't know.

rule_text_en: Short answers: Yes, I do. / No, he doesn't. Use do/does in the answer.
rule_text_uk: Короткі відповіді: Yes, I do. / No, he doesn't. Використовуй do/does у відповіді.
examples: Yes, I do.
No, she doesn't.
Yes, they do.

rule_text_en: With he/she/it, add -s (works). Spelling: -es (watches), -ies (studies), goes, does, has.
rule_text_uk: З he/she/it додаємо -s (works). Правопис: -es (watches), -ies (studies), goes, does, has.
examples: He teaches English.
She watches TV.
It goes fast.

rule_text_en: Present continuous = action happening now or around now (temporary situation).
rule_text_uk: Present Continuous = дія відбувається зараз або навколо цього часу (тимчасово).
examples: I'm staying with friends this week.
She's working late tonight.

rule_text_en: Present simple = things that happen regularly, habits, and permanent situations.
rule_text_uk: Present Simple = регулярні дії, звички та постійні ситуації.
examples: He plays tennis every Saturday.
They live near the station.

rule_text_en: Use present continuous for a situation in progress these days (not necessarily right now).
rule_text_uk: Вживай Present Continuous для ситуації, що триває зараз у цей період (не обовʼязково в цю секунду).
rule_short_en: In progress these days: present continuous.
examples: She's learning Spanish this year.
I'm looking for a new job these days.

rule_text_en: Use present simple for routines and things that happen repeatedly.
rule_text_uk: Вживай Present Simple для розпорядку та повторюваних дій.
examples: I start work at 9.
He usually walks to school.

rule_text_en: With always/constantly/forever, present continuous can show irritation or repeated behaviour.
rule_text_uk: З always/constantly/forever Present Continuous може виражати роздратування через повторювану поведінку.
examples: He's always losing his keys.
You're constantly complaining!

rule_text_en: Some verbs (know, like, believe, need) are not normally used in continuous forms.
rule_text_uk: Деякі дієслова (know, like, believe, need) зазвичай не вживаються в Continuous.
examples: I know the answer.
She likes this song.
We need some help.

rule_text_en: Use past simple for finished actions in the past (yesterday, last week, in 2019).
rule_text_uk: Вживай Past Simple для завершених дій у минулому (yesterday, last week, in 2019).
examples: We arrived at 8.
I bought a new phone last month.

rule_text_en: Regular verbs: -ed (work→worked). Irregular verbs: see→saw, go→went, have→had.
rule_text_uk: Правильні дієслова: -ed (work→worked). Неправильні: see→saw, go→went, have→had.
examples: She played tennis.
He went home early.
They had dinner.

rule_text_en: Negative and questions: did + base verb (I didn't go. Did you go?).
rule_text_uk: Заперечення й питання: did + базова форма (I didn't go. Did you go?).
examples: I didn't see him.
Did you call her?
Where did they stay?

rule_text_en: We often say when it happened: ago, last…, in…, on…, at…, yesterday.
rule_text_uk: Часто вказуємо час: ago, last…, in…, on…, at…, yesterday.
examples: I met her two years ago.
They left yesterday morning.

rule_text_en: Past continuous: was/were + verb-ing for an action in progress at a past time.
rule_text_uk: Past Continuous: was/were + -ing для дії, що тривала в певний момент у минулому.
examples: At 8 pm I was cooking.
They were watching a film.

rule_text_en: Use past continuous + past simple to show interruption: I was working when she called.
rule_text_uk: Past Continuous + Past Simple: показує переривання: I was working when she called.
rule_short_en: Interrupted action: was/were -ing + when + past simple.
examples: I was sleeping when the phone rang.
We were leaving when it started to rain.

rule_text_en: Use past continuous with while for two actions happening at the same time.
rule_text_uk: Past Continuous з while: дві дії відбувалися одночасно.
rule_short_en: Two actions at the same time: while + past continuous.
rule_short_uk: Дві одночасні дії: while + Past Continuous.
examples: While I was driving, he was reading the map.
She was cooking while I was setting the table.

rule_text_en: Questions/negatives: Was/Were ...? / wasn't/weren't + -ing.
rule_text_uk: Питання/заперечення: Was/Were ...? / wasn't/weren't + -ing.
rule_short_uk: Питання й заперечення в Past Continuous.
examples: Were you working yesterday?
He wasn't listening.

rule_text_en: Past continuous describes the background; past simple often tells the main event (sudden action).
rule_text_uk: Past Continuous описує фон; Past Simple часто передає основну подію (раптову дію).
examples: I was walking home when I saw Tom.
It was raining, so we stayed in.

rule_text_en: Present perfect: have/has + past participle (I have finished; she has gone).
rule_text_uk: Present Perfect: have/has + дієприкметник минулого (I have finished; she has gone).
examples: I've lost my keys.
She has broken her phone.

rule_text_en: Use present perfect for past actions with a result now (the time is not said).
rule_text_uk: Present Perfect для минулої дії з результатом зараз (час не називається).
examples: He's hurt his leg, so he can't run.
They've missed the bus.

rule_text_en: We use already, just, and yet with the present perfect to talk about recent news.
rule_text_uk: З Present Perfect вживаємо already, just, yet для нещодавніх подій/новин.
examples: I've just finished.
Have you eaten yet?
She's already left.

rule_text_en: For experiences in life, we often use ever/never with the present perfect.
rule_text_uk: Для життєвого досвіду часто вживаємо ever/never з Present Perfect.
examples: Have you ever been to Rome?
I've never tried sushi.

rule_text_en: Present perfect vs past simple: use present perfect when the time is not finished or not mentioned; use past simple with a finished time (yesterday, in 2020).
rule_text_uk: Present Perfect vs Past Simple: Present Perfect — коли час не завершений або не названий; Past Simple — з завершеним часом (yesterday, in 2020).
rule_short_en: Perfect (no finished time) vs past simple (finished time).
rule_short_uk: Perfect (час не завершений) vs Past Simple (завершений час).
examples: I've seen her today.
I saw her yesterday.

rule_text_en: Questions about details often use past simple: When did you go? What did you buy?
rule_text_uk: Питання про деталі часто в Past Simple: When did you go? What did you buy?
examples: When did you arrive?
How much did it cost?

rule_text_en: We often start with present perfect for news, then switch to past simple for details.
rule_text_uk: Часто починаємо з Present Perfect (новина), а потім переходимо на Past Simple (деталі).
rule_short_en: Perfect for news, past for details.
rule_short_uk: Perfect для новини, Past для деталей.
examples: I've bought a car. I got it last week.
She's met the boss. She met him on Monday.

rule_text_en: Present perfect continuous: have/has been + verb-ing for an activity that started in the past and is still continuing or has just stopped.
rule_text_uk: Present Perfect Continuous: have/has been + -ing для дії, що почалась у минулому і триває або щойно завершилась.
examples: I've been studying for two hours.
She's been running, so she's tired.

rule_text_en: We use it to focus on duration and activity (how long? all day? recently?).
rule_text_uk: Вживаємо, щоб підкреслити тривалість і процес (how long? all day? recently?).
examples: How long have you been waiting?
They've been working all morning.

rule_text_en: Present perfect simple often focuses on result (I've written 3 emails), while continuous focuses on activity (I've been writing emails).
rule_text_uk: Present Perfect Simple частіше про результат (I've written 3 emails), а Continuous — про процес (I've been writing emails).
examples: I've written five pages.
I've been writing for an hour.

rule_text_en: Use present perfect continuous for an unfinished activity; use present perfect simple for a finished result or number/amount.
rule_text_uk: Present Perfect Continuous — незавершений процес; Present Perfect Simple — завершений результат або кількість/обсяг.
examples: I've been cleaning the kitchen.
I've cleaned the kitchen.

rule_text_en: With for/since and how long, both forms are possible, but continuous is common for activities (I've been working here since June).
rule_text_uk: З for/since і how long можливі обидві форми, але для діяльності частіше Continuous (I've been working here since June).
examples: I've been living here for a year.
We've been waiting since 2 pm.

rule_text_en: We use the simple form with stative verbs (know, like, want): I've known him for years (not 'been knowing').
rule_text_uk: Зі стативними дієсловами (know, like, want) вживаємо Simple: I've known him for years (не 'been knowing').
rule_short_en: Stative verbs usually use perfect simple.
examples: I've known her since school.
I've always liked this place.

rule_text_en: Some verbs change meaning: I've been having problems (= experiencing) vs I've had a shower (= completed).
rule_text_uk: Деякі дієслова змінюють відтінок: I've been having problems (= маю) vs I've had a shower (= уже зробив).
rule_short_en: Meaning can differ between simple and continuous.
rule_short_uk: Значення може різнитися між Simple і Continuous.
examples: I've been having trouble sleeping.
I've had three cups of coffee today.

rule_text_en: Use present perfect for a situation that started in the past and continues now.
rule_text_uk: Present perfect — ситуація почалась у минулому і триває зараз.
rule_short_en: Started in the past and still true now → present perfect.
rule_short_uk: Почалось у минулому і триває → present perfect.
examples: I've lived here for five years.
She has worked here since 2021.
We have known each other a long time.

rule_text_en: Use for + a period (for two weeks) and since + the start point (since Monday).
rule_text_uk: for + період; since + точка старту.
examples: I've been busy for three days.
I've been busy since Tuesday.
They've been friends since school.

rule_text_en: With 'how long' we usually use present perfect continuous (have/has been doing).
rule_text_uk: З 'how long' зазвичай present perfect continuous.
rule_short_en: How long + activity → have been doing.
rule_short_uk: How long + дія → have been doing.
examples: How long have you been learning Spanish?
It's been raining all afternoon.
He's been driving for hours.

rule_text_en: State verbs are normally not continuous: 'How long have you known…?' not 'been knowing'.
rule_text_uk: Дієслова стану не в continuous: 'have you known' (не 'been knowing').
rule_short_en: State verbs: use simple, not continuous.
examples: How long have you known Mark?
I've had this cold since Friday.
We've liked this café for years.

rule_text_en: For is used with a length of time; since is used with the point when something started.
rule_text_uk: for — тривалість; since — момент початку.
examples: I've been here for an hour.
I've been here since 9 o’clock.
She's lived abroad since 2019.

rule_text_en: Ago is used with past simple to say how long before now something happened.
rule_text_uk: ago вживаємо з past simple, щоб сказати, скільки часу тому щось сталося.
rule_short_en: ago goes with past simple, not present perfect.
rule_short_uk: ago + past simple, не present perfect.
examples: I met her two weeks ago.
We moved here a year ago.
Did you call him five minutes ago?

rule_text_en: With 'how long', use present perfect (often continuous) and answer with for/since.
rule_text_uk: З 'how long' — present perfect (часто continuous) і відповіді for/since.
examples: How long have you been waiting?
I've been waiting for 20 minutes.
I've been waiting since 3 o’clock.

rule_text_en: It’s (been) … since … describes time from a past event until now.
rule_text_uk: 'It’s (been) … since …' — час від події в минулому до тепер.
rule_short_en: It’s been X since Y = time from Y until now.
rule_short_uk: It’s been X since Y = час від Y до тепер.
examples: It's been ages since we spoke.
It's been two months since I last saw her.
It's been ten minutes since the bus left.

rule_text_en: Use present perfect for past actions with a result now (I've lost my keys = I don't have them).
rule_text_uk: Present perfect — минула дія з результатом зараз.
examples: I've broken my glasses.
She's missed the train.
We've run out of milk.

rule_text_en: Use past simple for finished actions in a finished time (yesterday, last week, in 2018).
rule_text_uk: Past simple — завершена дія у завершеному часі.
examples: I called him yesterday.
They arrived last night.
We lived there in 2010.

rule_text_en: Don’t use present perfect with a past time expression (not 'I've seen him yesterday').
rule_text_uk: Не вживай present perfect з минулим часом (yesterday, last..., ago).
examples: I saw him yesterday.
We met two days ago.
Did you finish it last week?

rule_text_en: Use past simple, not present perfect, with a finished time: yesterday, last year, ten minutes ago.
rule_text_uk: З завершеним часом — past simple, не present perfect.
examples: I went home late last night.
She left ten minutes ago.
Did you see him yesterday?

rule_text_en: Use present perfect for time up to now (today, this week) if the period is not finished yet.
rule_text_uk: Present perfect — для періоду до тепер, який ще не закінчився.
examples: I've had three meetings today.
Have you seen Anna this week?
It's been quiet this morning.

rule_text_en: Past perfect (had done) shows one past action happened before another past time or event.
rule_text_uk: Past perfect (had done) — одна дія сталася раніше іншої в минулому.
examples: When I arrived, they had already left.
She couldn't pay because she'd forgotten her wallet.
I realized I'd seen him before.

rule_text_en: Often use past perfect with before/after to make the order clear.
rule_text_uk: Часто past perfect з before/after, щоб уточнити порядок.
rule_short_en: Use past perfect to make the order clear.
examples: After he'd finished, he went out.
I had locked the door before I left.
She left after she had spoken to him.

rule_text_en: If the order is obvious, past simple can be enough; past perfect is sometimes optional.
rule_text_uk: Якщо порядок ясний, інколи достатньо past simple; past perfect може бути необов’язковим.
rule_short_en: Past perfect optional if the order is obvious.
rule_short_uk: Може бути необов’язковим, якщо порядок ясний.
examples: I went to bed after I finished work.
He told me what happened earlier.
We arrived and the show started.

rule_text_en: Past perfect continuous (had been doing) describes an activity that continued up to a past moment.
rule_text_uk: Past perfect continuous — дія тривала до моменту в минулому.
rule_short_en: had been doing = duration up to a past point.
rule_short_uk: had been doing = тривалість до моменту в минулому.
examples: They had been waiting for an hour when the bus came.
I'd been studying for weeks before the exam.
She'd been working all day.

rule_text_en: Use it to explain a past result (tired, wet, angry) by a longer earlier activity.
rule_text_uk: Вживаємо, щоб пояснити минулий результат довшою попередньою дією.
rule_short_en: Past result + earlier activity → had been doing.
rule_short_uk: Минулий результат + дія → had been doing.
examples: His eyes were red—he'd been crying.
The ground was wet; it had been raining.
She was nervous; she'd been rehearsing.

rule_text_en: Compare: had been doing (process) vs had done (completed action) before a past time.
rule_text_uk: Порівняй: had been doing (процес) vs had done (завершено) до моменту в минулому.
rule_short_en: had been doing = process; had done = completed.
rule_short_uk: had been doing = процес; had done = завершено.
examples: I'd been writing for hours, but I hadn't finished.
I had written the email before lunch.
They had been walking, so they were exhausted.

rule_text_en: Often use for/since with had been doing to show duration up to that past moment.
rule_text_uk: Часто for/since з had been doing для тривалості до того моменту в минулому.
rule_short_en: for/since + had been doing (up to a past time).
rule_short_uk: for/since + had been doing (до моменту в минулому).
examples: He had been living there for years.
She'd been training since April.
We had been talking for 30 minutes.

rule_text_en: Have and have got mean the same for possession/relationships/illnesses. Present: I have / I've got.
rule_text_uk: Have і have got однакові для володіння/стосунків/недуг.
examples: I have a new phone.
I've got a sister.
She has a headache.

rule_text_en: For actions, use have (not have got): have breakfast, have a shower. Continuous is possible: I'm having a shower.
rule_text_uk: Для дій: have (не have got). Можна continuous: I'm having a shower.
examples: We had lunch at 1.
He's having a shower.
I don't usually have coffee.

rule_text_en: In questions/negatives with have (actions), use do/does/did: Do you have…? I don't have…
rule_text_uk: У питаннях/запереченнях з have (дії) — do/does/did.
examples: Do you have breakfast?
I don't have time.
Did you have trouble finding a hotel?

rule_text_en: Used to + infinitive describes past habits or states that are not true now.
rule_text_uk: Used to + інфінітив — минулі звички/стани, яких тепер немає.
rule_short_uk: used to = звичка/стан у минулому (тепер ні).
examples: I used to play chess every day.
She used to live in Kyiv.
They used to be very close.

rule_text_en: Negative: didn't use to… (or never used to…).
rule_text_uk: Заперечення: didn't use to… / never used to…
examples: I didn't use to like coffee.
He never used to wear glasses.
We didn't use to travel much.

rule_text_en: Questions: Did you use to…? (not 'used you to').
rule_text_uk: Питання: Did you use to…?
examples: Did you use to live here?
What games did you use to play?
Where did she use to work?

rule_text_en: Used to emphasises 'not now'. Past simple can describe single past events.
rule_text_uk: Used to підкреслює 'тепер ні'. Past simple може бути разовою подією.
rule_short_en: used to emphasises change; past simple can be one event.
rule_short_uk: used to підкреслює зміну; past simple може бути разово.
examples: I used to cycle to work, but now I drive.
I cycled to work yesterday.
She used to be shy, but now she's confident.

rule_text_en: Be/get used to + noun/gerund means 'be accustomed to': I'm used to getting up early.
rule_text_uk: Be/get used to + герундій/іменник = бути звиклим.
examples: I'm used to working late.
She's getting used to the cold.
We weren't used to the noise.

rule_text_en: Used to do (past habit) is different from be used to doing (accustomed).
rule_text_uk: Used to do (звичка) ≠ be used to doing (звиклий).
rule_short_en: used to do ≠ be used to doing.
rule_short_uk: used to do ≠ be used to doing.
examples: I used to read a lot, but now I don't.
I'm used to reading on my phone.
He used to travel; now he's used to staying home.

rule_text_en: Use present continuous for fixed arrangements: I'm meeting Anna tomorrow.
rule_text_uk: Present continuous — для домовленостей/планів у майбутньому.
examples: We're flying on Friday.
I'm seeing the dentist tomorrow.
They're coming for dinner tonight.

rule_text_en: Use present simple for timetables/schedules: The train leaves at 6.15.
rule_text_uk: Present simple — для розкладів/графіків.
examples: The lesson starts at 9.
The flight arrives at 18:40.
The shop opens at 10.

rule_text_en: Going to is used for intentions and plans: I'm going to buy a new laptop.
rule_text_uk: Going to — для намірів і планів.
examples: I'm going to call him later.
She's going to study medicine.
We're going to move soon.

rule_text_en: Going to is used for predictions based on present evidence: Look at those clouds—it's going to rain.
rule_text_uk: Going to — прогноз за теперішніми ознаками.
examples: It's going to be a long day.
He's going to fall!
That glass is going to break.

rule_text_en: Questions/negatives: Are you going to…? / I'm not going to…
rule_text_uk: Питання/заперечення: Are you going to…? / I'm not going to…
rule_short_en: Ask and negate with (be) going to.
examples: Are you going to stay?
I'm not going to argue.
Is she going to apply?

rule_text_en: Was/were going to expresses a past plan that did not happen or was changed.
rule_text_uk: Was/were going to — минулий план, який не відбувся або змінився.
rule_short_en: was/were going to = past plan (often not done).
rule_short_uk: was/were going to = минулий план (часто не зроблено).
examples: I was going to phone you, but I forgot.
They were going to travel, but they cancelled.
She was going to buy it, then changed her mind.

rule_text_en: Use I'll / I will for a decision made now (at the moment of speaking). Use won’t for a quick refusal or decision not to do something.
rule_text_uk: Використовуй I'll / I will для рішення, яке приймаєш зараз, у момент мовлення. Won’t — для швидкої відмови або рішення щось не робити.
rule_short_en: I'll = decision now; won't = refusal/decision not to.
rule_short_uk: I'll = рішення зараз; won't = відмова/рішення не робити.
examples: The phone is ringing. I’ll answer it.
I forgot my wallet. I’ll pay you back tomorrow.
I won’t tell anyone. It’s a secret.

rule_text_en: We often use I'll to offer help, agree, or promise. Use won’t to show refusal. Use Will you …? to ask someone to do something.
rule_text_uk: Ми часто вживаємо I'll, щоб запропонувати допомогу, погодитися або пообіцяти. Won’t показує відмову. Will you …? — прохання до співрозмовника.
examples: That box looks heavy. I’ll carry it.
Okay, I’ll email you tonight.
Will you close the window, please?

rule_text_en: Don’t use will for future plans that are already arranged or decided. Use present continuous, present simple, or going to for arrangements.
rule_text_uk: Не вживай will для планів, які вже домовлені або вирішені. Для домовленостей використовуй present continuous, present simple або going to.
rule_short_en: No will for fixed plans; use present/going to.
rule_short_uk: Для домовлених планів не will; використовуй present/going to.
examples: I’m meeting Sam at 6. (not I’ll meet)
We’re going to visit my parents this weekend.
The train leaves at 7.15.

rule_text_en: Use shall mostly in questions with I/we: Shall I …? / Shall we …? to offer, ask for advice, or suggest an idea.
rule_text_uk: Shall зазвичай уживають у питаннях з I/we: Shall I …? / Shall we …? — щоб запропонувати, попросити поради або запропонувати ідею.
examples: Shall I open the window?
Shall we go by taxi?
What shall we do next?

rule_text_en: Use will to predict the future or say what you believe will happen. Don’t use will for plans already arranged or decided.
rule_text_uk: Will вживають для прогнозів і того, що, на твою думку, станеться. Не використовуй will для планів, які вже домовлені або вирішені.
rule_short_en: Will = prediction, not a fixed plan.
examples: I think it’ll snow tonight.
You’ll love that film.
She’s meeting the client tomorrow. (planned)

rule_text_en: We often use will with words like probably, I think, I’m sure, I don’t think. After hope, we usually use the present (I hope it rains / doesn’t rain).
rule_text_uk: Will часто вживають із probably, I think, I’m sure, I don’t think. Після hope зазвичай уживаємо теперішній час (I hope it rains / doesn’t rain).
rule_short_en: Will + probably/I think… ; after hope → present.
rule_short_uk: Will + probably/I think… ; після hope → present.
examples: I’ll probably be home late.
I don’t think they’ll agree.
I hope you feel better soon.

rule_text_en: We normally use will for the future, but we can also use will to talk about now when we make a guess about the present (She’ll be busy).
rule_text_uk: Зазвичай will — про майбутнє, але інколи will уживають і про теперішнє, коли робимо припущення (She’ll be busy).
rule_short_en: Will can mean a guess about now.
rule_short_uk: Will може означати припущення про тепер.
examples: Don’t call him; he’ll be asleep now.
They’ll be in a meeting at the moment.
She’ll know the answer.

rule_text_en: Shall is used mainly with I/we (often formal): I shall / we shall. The negative is shan’t or shall not. In everyday speech, we usually say I’ll / we’ll.
rule_text_uk: Shall вживають головно з I/we (часто офіційно): I shall / we shall. Заперечення — shan’t або shall not. У повсякденній мові частіше кажуть I’ll / we’ll.
rule_short_en: Shall is mainly I/we; shan’t = negative.
rule_short_uk: Shall переважно з I/we; shan’t = заперечення.
examples: We shall contact you soon.
I shan’t be long.
We’ll see you tomorrow.

rule_text_en: For future actions: use will when you decide at the moment; use (be) going to when the decision was made earlier.
rule_text_uk: Для майбутніх дій: will — коли рішення приймаєш у момент мовлення; (be) going to — коли рішення було прийняте раніше.
rule_short_en: Will = decision now; going to = plan already decided.
rule_short_uk: Will = рішення зараз; going to = план уже вирішений.
examples: I’m tired. I’ll go to bed early.
I’m going to buy a new laptop next week.
Thanks. I’ll call you back in a minute.

rule_text_en: For predictions, both will and going to are possible. Use going to when there is evidence now; use will for general expectations or opinions.
rule_text_uk: Для прогнозів можливі і will, і going to. Going to — коли є ознаки зараз; will — для загальних очікувань або думок.
examples: Look at those clouds. It’s going to rain.
I think the team will win.
The car is making a strange noise. It’s going to stop.

rule_text_en: Use will be doing for an action in progress at a future time. Use will have done for an action completed before a future time.
rule_text_uk: Will be doing — дія буде тривати в певний момент у майбутньому. Will have done — дія завершиться до певного моменту в майбутньому.
rule_short_en: Will be doing = in progress; will have done = finished by then.
rule_short_uk: Will be doing = у процесі; will have done = завершено до того часу.
examples: At 9 tomorrow I’ll be flying to Rome.
By 9 tomorrow I’ll have arrived in Rome.
This time next week we’ll be travelling.

rule_text_en: Will be doing (future continuous) = you will be in the middle of doing something. Compare: I’ll be eating (in progress) vs I’ll eat (simple).
rule_text_uk: Will be doing (future continuous) = ти будеш у процесі дії. Порівняй: I’ll be eating (у процесі) vs I’ll eat (простий факт/рішення).
rule_short_en: Future continuous = in the middle of an action.
examples: Don’t call at 8; I’ll be driving.
At noon we’ll be having lunch.
She’ll be working late tonight.

rule_text_en: We also use will be -ing to describe a future activity (often as a natural/expected situation), sometimes sounding more polite than will do.
rule_text_uk: Will be -ing також уживають, щоб описати майбутню діяльність як «нормальну»/очікувану; інколи це звучить ввічливіше, ніж will do.
rule_short_en: Will be -ing can describe expected future activity.
rule_short_uk: Will be -ing описує очікувану майбутню діяльність.
examples: I’ll be seeing Alex later, so I can ask him.
Will you be using your car this evening?
The manager will be meeting the team tomorrow.

rule_text_en: Will have done (future perfect) means something will be complete before a time in the future. Often used with by + time.
rule_text_uk: Will have done (future perfect) означає, що щось буде завершено до певного моменту в майбутньому. Часто з by + time.
rule_short_en: Future perfect = completed by a future time.
rule_short_uk: Future perfect = завершено до майбутнього моменту.
examples: By Friday, we’ll have finished the report.
She’ll have left by the time you arrive.
In two years they’ll have been married for ten years.

rule_text_en: After when, before, after, as soon as, until, while etc. we use the present (not will) to talk about the future: when I arrive, before you go.
rule_text_uk: Після when, before, after, as soon as, until, while тощо для майбутнього вживаємо теперішній час (не will): when I arrive, before you go.
rule_short_en: After time words, use present for the future.
rule_short_uk: Після слів часу — present для майбутнього.
examples: I’ll text you when I get home.
Please lock the door before you leave.
Wait here until I come back.

rule_text_en: We can use the present perfect after when/after/as soon as/until to show one action finishes before another: when I’ve finished, I’ll call. Don’t use it if actions happen together.
rule_text_uk: Можна вживати present perfect після when/after/as soon as/until, щоб показати, що одна дія завершиться раніше: when I’ve finished, I’ll call. Не вживай, якщо дії відбуваються одночасно.
rule_short_en: Present perfect shows 'finished before' after time words.
rule_short_uk: Present perfect показує «завершиться раніше» після слів часу.
examples: When I’ve saved enough, I’ll buy a car.
As soon as you’ve sent it, let me know.
When I arrive, I’ll call you. (together → present simple)

rule_text_en: After if, we use the present for the future (If it rains, we’ll stay in). Use if for something possible; use when for something expected/sure.
rule_text_uk: Після if для майбутнього вживаємо present (If it rains, we’ll stay in). If — для можливого; when — для очікуваного/певного.
rule_short_en: If = possible; when = expected. Both use present.
rule_short_uk: If = можливе; when = очікуване. Обидва з present.
examples: If I see Maya, I’ll tell her.
When I see Maya, I’ll tell her.
If you don’t hurry, you’ll miss the bus.

rule_text_en: Use can to talk about ability, permission, or possibility in the present. The negative is can’t / cannot.
rule_text_uk: Can вживають для здібності, дозволу або можливості в теперішньому. Заперечення — can’t / cannot.
examples: I can swim, but I can’t dive.
You can park here after 6.
We can see the mountains from the window.

rule_text_en: (Be) able to is similar to can, but it is needed when we use other forms (infinitive, future, perfect): I’ve been able to…, I’ll be able to…
rule_text_uk: (Be) able to схоже на can, але потрібне в інших формах (інфінітив, майбутній, перфект): I’ve been able to…, I’ll be able to…
rule_short_en: Able to replaces can in other tenses/forms.
rule_short_uk: Able to замінює can в інших часах/формах.
examples: I’ll be able to help you tomorrow.
Have you ever been able to cook well?
I haven’t been able to sleep lately.

rule_text_en: Could is often the past of can. We use could especially with verbs like see, hear, feel, remember, understand.
rule_text_uk: Could часто є минулим часом від can. Особливо could вживають з дієсловами see, hear, feel, remember, understand.
rule_short_en: Could = past of can (often with senses).
rule_short_uk: Could = минулий від can (часто з відчуттями).
examples: It was dark, but I could see the sign.
I could hear music from next door.
When I was a child, I could run fast.

rule_text_en: Use could for general ability in the past. For a specific successful action in one situation, we usually say was/were able to or managed to (not could).
rule_text_uk: Could — для загальної здібності в минулому. Для конкретної успішної дії в певній ситуації зазвичай кажемо was/were able to або managed to (не could).
rule_short_en: Past success in one situation: was able to / managed to.
rule_short_uk: Успіх у конкретній ситуації: was able to / managed to.
examples: We were able to find a hotel in the end.
I managed to open the door.
When I was young, I could skate. (general)

rule_text_en: Could can be the past of can, but it is also used for possible actions now or in the future (suggestions). It is less certain than can.
rule_text_uk: Could може бути минулим від can, але також вживається для можливих дій зараз або в майбутньому (пропозиції). Це менш упевнено, ніж can.
examples: We could go for a walk later.
You could ask Nina about it.
It could rain this evening.

rule_text_en: We use could (not can) for unreal or imagined situations: I could sleep all day (but I won’t).
rule_text_uk: Could (не can) вживають для нереальних або уявних ситуацій: I could sleep all day (але не буду).
examples: I’m so tired I could fall asleep anywhere.
I could live here forever.
That dress is lovely; it could be expensive.

rule_text_en: Use could to say something is possible now or later. Compare: can change (general) vs could change (possible in this situation).
rule_text_uk: Could вживають, щоб сказати, що щось можливе зараз або пізніше. Порівняй: can change (загалом) vs could change (у цій ситуації).
examples: The plan could change if the weather gets worse.
Be careful; the floor could be slippery.
Traffic could be heavy at this time.

rule_text_en: Could have (done) means it was possible in the past, but it did not happen.
rule_text_uk: Could have (done) означає: у минулому це було можливим, але не сталося.
rule_short_en: Could have done = possible but didn’t happen.
rule_short_uk: Could have done = могло статися, але не сталося.
examples: I could have called you, but I forgot.
They could have won the match.
You could have hurt yourself.

rule_text_en: Couldn’t do = it isn’t/wasn’t possible. Couldn’t have (done) = it was impossible in the past (it could not have happened).
rule_text_uk: Couldn’t do = неможливо (зараз/тоді). Couldn’t have (done) = у минулому це було неможливо (не могло статися).
rule_short_en: Couldn’t = impossible; couldn’t have = impossible in the past.
rule_short_uk: Couldn’t = неможливо; couldn’t have = неможливо в минулому.
examples: I couldn’t lift the box.
It couldn’t have been him; he was abroad.
The holiday couldn’t have been better.

rule_text_en: Use must to say you are sure something is true (a strong deduction). Use can’t to say you are sure something is impossible.
rule_text_uk: Must вживають, коли ти впевнений, що це правда (сильний висновок). Can’t — коли впевнений, що це неможливо.
examples: You’ve worked all day. You must be exhausted.
They can’t be at home; the lights are off.
He must know the answer.

rule_text_en: For the past, use must have / can’t have: She must have forgotten. He can’t have seen us. (Couldn’t have is also possible.)
rule_text_uk: Для минулого вживають must have / can’t have: She must have forgotten. He can’t have seen us. (Також можливе couldn’t have.)
rule_short_en: Past deduction: must have / can’t have.
rule_short_uk: Висновок про минуле: must have / can’t have.
examples: The door was locked. They must have left.
He can’t have said that. It’s not like him.
I must have dropped my keys somewhere.

rule_text_en: Use may or might to say something is possible (now). Negatives: may not / might not. Note: may be (two words) vs maybe (one word).
rule_text_uk: May або might вживають, щоб сказати, що щось можливе (зараз). Заперечення: may not / might not. Різниця: may be (два слова) і maybe (одне слово).
examples: She may be in her office.
It might not be true.
Maybe we should leave now.

rule_text_en: For the past, use may have / might have (and may not / might not have) to say something was possible.
rule_text_uk: Для минулого вживай may have / might have (і may not / might not have), щоб сказати, що щось було можливим.
examples: She might have missed the bus.
He may not have heard you.
I may have left my phone at work.

rule_text_en: Could is similar to may/might in positive sentences (It could be true). But couldn’t means ‘impossible’, not ‘perhaps not’.
rule_text_uk: Could схоже на may/might у ствердженнях (It could be true). Але couldn’t означає «неможливо», а не «можливо ні».
examples: It could be my mistake.
He couldn’t be 15 — he’s at least 20.
They might not know.

rule_text_en: Use may/might to talk about possible future actions or situations. Negatives: may not / might not (mightn’t).
rule_text_uk: May/might вживають для можливих дій або ситуацій у майбутньому. Заперечення: may not / might not (mightn’t).
examples: I may go out later.
It might rain this afternoon.
We might have to wait a bit.

rule_text_en: We use might (not may) when the situation is unreal or imaginary, often with if: If I had more time, I might learn Italian.
rule_text_uk: Might (не may) вживають, коли ситуація нереальна/уявна, часто з if: If I had more time, I might learn Italian.
examples: If I were taller, I might play basketball.
If they paid more, I might stay.
If I knew his number, I might call him.

rule_text_en: Use may/might be -ing to talk about possible future plans or what someone could be doing at a future time. Compare with will be -ing (more certain).
rule_text_uk: May/might be -ing вживають для можливих планів або того, що хтось може робити в певний момент у майбутньому. Порівняй з will be -ing (більш певно).
rule_short_en: May/might be -ing = possible activity at a future time.
rule_short_uk: May/might be -ing = можлива дія в майбутній момент.
examples: Don’t call at 9; I might be studying.
She may be meeting a client tomorrow morning.
We’ll be travelling next week.

rule_text_en: Might as well means ‘do it because there is no better alternative’. It can also be may as well.
rule_text_uk: Might as well означає «краще вже зробити, бо немає кращого варіанту». Також можливе may as well.
rule_short_en: Might as well = no better alternative.
rule_short_uk: Might as well = немає кращого варіанту.
examples: It’s already late, so we might as well stay here.
The shop is open, so I may as well go in.
We’ve missed the bus — we might as well walk.

rule_text_en: Use have to for necessity or obligation (a fact). Use do/does/did for questions and negatives: Do I have to...? I don't have to...; I had to... for the past.
rule_text_uk: Використовуйте have to для необхідності/обовʼязку (факт). У питаннях і запереченнях: do/does/did + have to. Для минулого: had to.
rule_short_en: have to = necessary/obliged; questions/negatives use do/does/did.
rule_short_uk: have to = треба; питання/заперечення з do/does/did.
examples: I have to wear glasses to read.
Do we have to leave now?
I didn't have to wait long.

rule_text_en: Must is close to have to, but it often shows the speaker's view or recommendation. For facts we usually use have to. In written rules, must is common. For the past, use had to.
rule_text_uk: Must подібне до have to, але часто передає думку/рекомендацію мовця або правило. Для фактів зазвичай have to. У минулому: had to.
rule_short_en: Must = speaker's view / rules; have to = fact; past = had to.
rule_short_uk: must = думка/правило; have to = факт; минуле = had to.
examples: You must try this cake - it's fantastic.
Employees must show an ID badge.
Yesterday I had to leave early.

rule_text_en: Have got to can replace have to in the present (informal): I've got to go = I have to go.
rule_text_uk: Have got to можна вживати замість have to в теперішньому (розмовно): I've got to go = I have to go.
rule_short_en: have got to = informal have to (present).
rule_short_uk: have got to = розмовне have to (теперішній).
examples: I've got to call my sister.
What time have you got to be there?

rule_text_en: Mustn't means 'don't do it' (prohibited). Don't have to means 'not necessary' (optional). They are different.
rule_text_uk: Mustn't = заборонено (не роби). Don't have to = не обовʼязково (можеш не робити).
rule_short_en: mustn't = forbidden; don't have to = not necessary.
rule_short_uk: mustn't = заборонено; don't have to = не обовʼязково.
examples: You mustn't park here.
You don't have to come if you're busy.
We mustn't be late.

rule_text_en: Must means 'it's necessary' (strong obligation). Mustn't means 'don't do it' (prohibition).
rule_text_uk: Must = необхідно. Mustn't = не можна (заборона).
examples: You must keep this secret.
You mustn't touch the wires.
We must hurry.

rule_text_en: Needn't means 'not necessary' (you can if you want). You can also say don't/doesn't need to. We say needn't do (without 'to').
rule_text_uk: Needn't = не потрібно (але можна). Також: don't/doesn't need to. Кажемо needn't do (без to).
rule_short_en: needn't = not necessary; also don't need to.
rule_short_uk: needn't = не потрібно; також don't need to.
examples: You needn't wait for me.
We don't need to hurry.
He needn't come today.

rule_text_en: Needn't have done = you did something, but later you see it was unnecessary: You needn't have bought tickets (but you did).
rule_text_uk: Needn't have done: ви це зробили, але потім стало ясно, що це було не потрібно.
rule_short_en: needn't have done: did it, but it wasn't necessary.
examples: You needn't have cooked so much.
She needn't have taken a taxi.
We needn't have booked ahead.

title_en: needn't have vs didn't need to
rule_text_en: Needn't have done: you did it unnecessarily. Didn't need to do: it wasn't necessary; maybe you didn't do it (or you did).
rule_text_uk: Needn't have done: зробив даремно. Didn't need to do: потреби не було; головне — «не потрібно було».
rule_short_en: needn't have = did it unnecessarily; didn't need to = no need.
rule_short_uk: needn't have = зробив даремно; didn't need to = не було потреби.
examples: I didn't need to call, so I didn't.
I didn't need to call, but I did anyway.
You needn't have called - everything was fine.

rule_text_en: Use should to give advice or say what is a good/right thing to do. Use shouldn't to say something is not a good idea.
rule_text_uk: Should — порада/правильна дія. Shouldn't — не варто, погана ідея.
examples: You should get some rest.
You shouldn't drive when you're tired.
Do you think I should call her?

rule_text_en: Use should when something is expected or when a situation isn't right: She should be here by now; It shouldn't take long.
rule_text_uk: Should вживаємо для очікуваного або коли щось «не так»: She should be here by now; It shouldn't take long.
examples: The train should arrive at 6.
He should be home by now.
It shouldn't be difficult to park.

rule_text_en: Should have done = it would have been better to do it (but you didn't). Shouldn't have done = it was a bad idea (and you did it).
rule_text_uk: Should have done: було б краще зробити (але не зробив). Shouldn't have done: не треба було робити (але зробив).
rule_short_en: should have = regret about not doing; shouldn't have = regret about doing.
rule_short_uk: should have = шкода, що не зробив; shouldn't have = шкода, що зробив.
examples: You should have told me earlier.
I shouldn't have said that.
You should have come with us.

rule_text_en: Ought to can replace should. We usually use 'ought to' (with 'to') and can say ought not to / ought to have done.
rule_text_uk: Ought to можна замінити should; зазвичай з to: ought to / ought not to / ought to have done.
examples: You ought to see a doctor.
He ought not to speak like that.
You ought to have phoned me.

rule_text_en: Use should after verbs like insist, demand, recommend, suggest, propose: They suggested that we should leave early.
rule_text_uk: Should ставимо після insist/demand/recommend/suggest/propose: They suggested that we should leave.
examples: I insisted that he should apologise.
They recommended that we should book ahead.

rule_text_en: In these structures, we can omit should: They suggested that we leave early. This is a subjunctive form (base verb).
rule_text_uk: У структурах з A можна опустити should: suggested that we leave. Це умовний/субʼюнктив (базова форма дієслова).
rule_short_en: You can drop should: suggested that we leave / be / do.
rule_short_uk: Можна без should: suggested that we leave / be / do.
examples: It's essential that everyone be on time.
She insisted that he apologise.

rule_text_en: With suggest, we use a that-clause (with should or subjunctive) and not 'to': What do you suggest we do?
rule_text_uk: Після suggest вживаємо that‑clause, а не to: What do you suggest we do? (не suggest us to do).
rule_short_en: suggest + that we (should) do / suggest we do (no 'to').
examples: What do you suggest we do?
I suggested that she buy a used car.

rule_text_en: Use should after adjectives like strange, odd, natural, important, surprised: It's strange that he should be late.
rule_text_uk: Should після прикметників типу strange/important/surprised: It's strange that he should be late.
examples: It's odd that she should say that.
I was surprised that he should agree.

rule_text_en: If something should happen means 'if it happens' but feels less likely. You can also start with Should: Should anything happen, call me.
rule_text_uk: If ... should ... = «якщо раптом...», менш імовірно. Можна почати з Should: Should anything happen, ...
rule_short_en: If ... should ... = less likely; Should ... happen = same meaning.
rule_short_uk: If ... should ... = менш імовірно; Should ... happen = те саме.
examples: If you should see Dan, tell him.
Should the weather change, we'll stay home.

rule_text_en: Use I should / I shouldn't to say what you will do or advise in a situation: 'Shall I wait?' 'No, I should go now.'
rule_text_uk: I should / I shouldn't — що я зроблю/пораджу в ситуації: ‘Shall I wait?' ‘No, I should go.'
rule_short_en: I should ... = what I'll do / advise in this case.
examples: I should phone her tonight.
I shouldn't stay up late.
I should take a coat.

rule_text_en: Had better ('d better) gives strong advice for a specific situation, often with a possible problem if you don't do it. Negative: 'd better not.
rule_text_uk: Had better ('d better) — сильна порада для конкретної ситуації, часто з ризиком. Заперечення: 'd better not.
rule_short_en: 'd better = strong advice for this situation; 'd better not = avoid.
rule_short_uk: 'd better = сильна порада; 'd better not = краще не.
examples: You'd better leave now or you'll miss the train.
We'd better not tell him yet.
I'd better call her.

rule_text_en: Had better is for one specific situation and sounds like there is a risk. Should is more general advice and doesn't imply a problem if you don't do it.
rule_text_uk: Had better — конкретна ситуація і звучить як попередження про проблему. Should — загальна порада.
rule_short_en: had better = specific + risk; should = general advice.
rule_short_uk: had better = конкретно+ризик; should = загальна порада.
examples: It's late - you'd better go.
You should exercise regularly.
You'd better not be late.

rule_text_en: It's time (for somebody) to do something. You can also use past: It's time we went. It's time somebody did something = they should have started already; often a complaint. Also: it's about time ...
rule_text_uk: It's time (for sb) to do...; також past: It's time we went. It's time somebody did... — «вже пора», часто скарга. Також: it's about time...
rule_short_en: It's time to... / It's time we went / It's time you did... (complaint).
rule_short_uk: It's time to... / It's time we went / It's time you did...
examples: It's time to go home.
It's time we left.
It's about time you apologised.

rule_text_en: Use would / wouldn't to imagine a situation that isn’t real now; use would have + past participle to imagine a different past.
rule_text_uk: Використовуй would / wouldn't, щоб уявити ситуацію, яка нереальна зараз; would have + дієприкметник — щоб уявити інше минуле.
rule_short_en: Would = imagined (not real); would have = imagined past.
rule_short_uk: Would = уява (не реальність); would have = уявне минуле.
examples: I’d buy a bigger flat if I could afford it.
I wouldn’t say that in your place.
Without your help, we’d have been lost.

rule_text_en: In reported speech, will often becomes would: He said he’d call. Wouldn’t can mean ‘refused’ (a person or thing wouldn’t do it).
rule_text_uk: У непрямій мові will часто змінюється на would: He said he’d call. Wouldn’t також може означати «відмовився» (людина або річ).
rule_short_en: Will → would in reports; wouldn’t = refused.
examples: She promised she wouldn’t be late.
I asked him twice, but he wouldn’t answer.
The engine wouldn’t start.

rule_text_en: Would can describe repeated actions in the past (past habits), often with time expressions like when/whenever.
rule_text_uk: Would може описувати повторювані дії в минулому (звички), часто з when/whenever.
examples: When we were kids, we’d play outside till dark.
Whenever he got stressed, he’d go for a long walk.

rule_text_en: For requests, use Can you…? / Could you…? Could is usually more polite. You can also say Do you think you could…?
rule_text_uk: Для прохання використовуй Can you…? / Could you…? Could зазвичай звучить ввічливіше. Також: Do you think you could…?
examples: Could you open the window, please?
Do you think you could help me for a minute?

rule_text_en: To ask permission, use Can I…? / Could I…? (May I…? is more formal). You can also use Do you mind if…? / Is it OK if…?
rule_text_uk: Щоб попросити дозвіл, використовуй Can I…? / Could I…? (May I…? — більш формально). Також: Do you mind if…? / Is it OK if…?
rule_short_en: Permission: Can/Could I…?; Do you mind if…?
rule_short_uk: Дозвіл: Can/Could I…?; Do you mind if…?
examples: Could I borrow your charger for a moment?
Is it OK if I sit here?

rule_text_en: For offers/invitations, use Can I…? (offer) and Would you like…? (invite/offer). I’d like… is a polite way to say what you want.
rule_text_uk: Для пропозицій/запрошень: Can I…? (пропозиція допомоги) та Would you like…? (запрошення/пропозиція). I’d like… — ввічливо сказати, чого ти хочеш.
rule_short_en: Offers: Can I…?; Invitations: Would you like…?; I’d like…
rule_short_uk: Пропозиції: Can I…?; Запрошення: Would you like…?; I’d like…
examples: Can I carry that for you?
Would you like some tea?
I’d like a receipt, please.

rule_text_en: Use if + present to talk about a real future possibility, often with will/can in the main clause.
rule_text_uk: Використовуй if + теперішній час для реальної можливості в майбутньому; у головній частині часто will/can.
examples: If it rains, we’ll stay at home.
If you hurry, you can catch the bus.

rule_text_en: Use if + past to imagine an unreal or unlikely situation now/future, with would/could/might in the main clause.
rule_text_uk: Використовуй if + минулий час, щоб уявити нереальну або малоймовірну ситуацію зараз/у майбутньому; у головній частині would/could/might.
examples: If I had more time, I’d learn Italian.
If we went by taxi, it might be faster.

rule_text_en: Don’t usually use would in the if-clause: If I won…, I’d buy…. Use would (or could/might) in the main clause instead.
rule_text_uk: Зазвичай не вживай would у частині з if: If I won…, I’d buy…. Would (або could/might) став у головній частині.
rule_short_uk: Зазвичай без would у частині з if.
examples: If she called, I’d answer.
If it stopped raining, we could go out.

rule_text_en: Second conditional: if + past, would + base verb for an unreal situation now/future (If I knew…, I’d… ).
rule_text_uk: Друга умова: if + минулий час, would + інфінітив для нереальної ситуації зараз/у майбутньому (If I knew…, I’d… ).
rule_short_uk: If + минулий, would = нереальне зараз/у майбутньому.
examples: If I were you, I’d wait.
I’d help if I could.

rule_text_en: Wish for the present: I wish + past to show you’re unhappy about the situation now (I wish I had more time).
rule_text_uk: Wish про теперішнє: I wish + минулий час, щоб показати невдоволення ситуацією зараз (I wish I had more time).
rule_short_en: I wish + past = unhappy about now.
examples: I wish I lived closer to work.
I wish it wasn’t so noisy.

rule_text_en: After if and wish, were is common instead of was (If I were / I wish it were). Was is also possible in informal English.
rule_text_uk: Після if і wish часто вживають were замість was (If I were / I wish it were). У розмовній мові можливе й was.
rule_short_en: If I were / I wish it were (was also possible).
rule_short_uk: If I were / I wish it were (was теж можливе).
examples: If I were taller, I’d play basketball.
I wish he were here.

rule_text_en: We don’t usually say if … would. Put would in the main clause. Also, don’t say wish … would have … (see Unit 40).
rule_text_uk: Зазвичай не кажуть if … would. Would став у головній частині. Також не кажуть wish … would have … (див. Unit 40).
examples: If I had the key, I would open the door.
Who would you call if you needed help?

rule_text_en: Could can mean ‘would be able to’ in the main clause, or ‘was/were able to’ in the if-clause, depending on the context.
rule_text_uk: Could може означати «міг би» у головній частині або «міг/могла» (здатність) у частині з if — залежно від контексту.
rule_short_en: Could = would be able / was able (context).
examples: If I could drive, I’d rent a car.
She could get a better job if she could speak German.

rule_text_en: Third conditional: if + had + past participle, would have + past participle to imagine a different past result.
rule_text_uk: Третя умова: if + had + дієприкметник, would have + дієприкметник — щоб уявити інший результат у минулому.
rule_short_en: If + had done, would have done = unreal past.
rule_short_uk: If + had done, would have done = нереальне минуле.
examples: If we’d left earlier, we would have caught the train.
If I’d known, I would have told you.

rule_text_en: Wish about the past: I wish + past perfect to show regret. Don’t use wish … would have …
rule_text_uk: Wish про минуле: I wish + past perfect, щоб показати жаль. Не використовуй wish … would have …
rule_short_en: I wish + had done = regret about the past.
rule_short_uk: I wish + had done = жаль про минуле.
examples: I wish I hadn’t said that.
I wish we’d taken a taxi.

rule_text_en: Mixed time: If I’d done …, I would be … (present result). If I’d done …, I would have done … (past result).
rule_text_uk: Змішаний час: If I’d done …, I would be … (результат зараз). If I’d done …, I would have done … (результат у минулому).
rule_short_en: Would be (now) vs would have done (past).
rule_short_uk: Would be (зараз) vs would have done (минуле).
examples: If I’d gone to bed earlier, I’d feel better now.
If she’d come, she would have met everyone.

rule_text_en: With third conditional, you can also use could have (ability) and might have (possibility) instead of would have.
rule_text_uk: У третій умові можна також вживати could have (здатність) і might have (можливість) замість would have.
rule_short_en: Could have = ability; might have = possibility.
rule_short_uk: Could have = здатність; might have = можливість.
examples: If you’d asked, I could have helped.
If it hadn’t rained, we might have gone out.

rule_text_en: Use wish + noun/phrase to say good things to someone (wish you luck, a pleasant trip). Use hope (not wish) for 'I hope you feel better'.
rule_text_uk: Використовуй wish + іменник/фразу, щоб побажати комусь чогось (wish you luck, a pleasant trip). Для 'I hope you feel better' вживай hope (не wish).
rule_short_en: Wish someone luck; hope for a situation.
rule_short_uk: Побажання: wish; сподівання про ситуацію: hope.
examples: I wish you good luck in your interview.
We hope you get well soon.
I wished them a safe journey.

rule_text_en: For present regret: wish + past simple (knew, had, were). The meaning is now: I wish I knew (= I don't know).
rule_text_uk: Для жалю про теперішнє: wish + Past Simple (knew, had, were). Значення стосується тепер: I wish I knew (= я не знаю).
rule_short_uk: Жаль про теперішнє: wish + Past Simple.
examples: I wish I lived nearer the sea.
She wishes she had more time.
I wish it wasn't so cold.

rule_text_en: For past regret: wish + past perfect (had done). Also: wish + could / could have to regret lack of ability now or in the past.
rule_text_uk: Для жалю про минуле: wish + Past Perfect (had done). Також: wish + could / could have — жаль, що не можу/не зміг(ла) щось зробити.
rule_short_en: Past regret: wish + had done; wish + could.
rule_short_uk: Жаль про минуле: wish + Past Perfect; wish + could.
examples: I wish I had told you earlier.
I wish I could speak Japanese.
They wish they could have come.

rule_text_en: Use wish + would/wouldn't to say you want something to change or to complain: I wish it would stop. I wish you wouldn't interrupt.
rule_text_uk: Використовуй wish + would/wouldn't, щоб сказати, що хочеш змін або поскаржитися: I wish it would stop. I wish you wouldn't interrupt.
examples: I wish the baby would go to sleep.
I wish you wouldn't shout.
I wish somebody would answer the phone.

rule_text_en: Active focuses on the doer (Somebody built the house). Passive focuses on the thing affected (The house was built).
rule_text_uk: Актив підкреслює виконавця (Somebody built the house). Пасив підкреслює об’єкт дії (The house was built).
examples: Somebody stole my bike. / My bike was stolen.
They make these cars in Japan. / These cars are made in Japan.

rule_text_en: Form: be (am/is/are/was/were) + past participle (done, cleaned, built). Tense is on be.
rule_text_uk: Форма: be (am/is/are/was/were) + дієприкметник минулого часу (done, cleaned, built). Час показує be.
examples: The room is cleaned every day.
The bridge was built in 1981.
The documents were signed.

rule_text_en: Use by + agent when it matters: The book was written by Orwell. Often we omit the agent if unknown or not important.
rule_text_uk: Використовуй by + виконавець, якщо це важливо: The book was written by Orwell. Часто виконавця опускають, якщо він невідомий або неважливий.
rule_short_en: Add by + agent only when needed.
examples: The window was broken (by a stone).
The painting was sold by the artist.

rule_text_en: Perfect passive: has/have been + past participle; had been + past participle. It shows the action is completed before now/before a past time.
rule_text_uk: Пасив у Perfect: has/have been + дієприкметник; had been + дієприкметник. Дія завершена до тепер/до минулого моменту.
rule_short_en: Perfect passive: has been / had been done.
rule_short_uk: Perfect passive: has been / had been done.
examples: The flight has been cancelled.
The room had been cleaned before we arrived.
I haven't been invited.

rule_text_en: Continuous passive: am/is/are being + past participle; was/were being + past participle. It describes an action in progress.
rule_text_uk: Тривалий пасив: am/is/are being + дієприкметник; was/were being + дієприкметник. Дія в процесі.
rule_short_en: Continuous passive: is being / was being done.
rule_short_uk: Тривалий пасив: is being / was being done.
examples: A new road is being built.
We were being watched.
The room is being painted.

rule_text_en: Passive infinitive: (to) be + past participle (must be done, wants to be left).
rule_text_uk: Пасивний інфінітив: (to) be + дієприкметник (must be done, wants to be left).
examples: Something must be done now.
I want to be left alone.
The forms need to be signed.

rule_text_en: Perfect infinitive passive: (to) have been + past participle (should have been sent).
rule_text_uk: Пасивний Perfect-інфінітив: (to) have been + дієприкметник (should have been sent).
rule_short_en: Perfect infinitive passive: to have been done.
rule_short_uk: Perfect-інфінітив пасиву: to have been done.
examples: The letter should have been posted yesterday.
It might have been sent to the wrong address.
The door should have been locked.

rule_text_en: With verbs like give/offer/show, we often start the passive with the person: I was offered a job. She was shown a copy.
rule_text_uk: З дієсловами give/offer/show тощо часто починаємо пасив з людини: I was offered a job. She was shown a copy.
rule_short_uk: Дієслова з двома об’єктами: пасив з людини.
examples: I was given a refund.
We were offered a discount.
He was taught English.

rule_text_en: Alternative passive: the thing becomes the subject and we use to/for: The job was offered to me. The money was paid to her.
rule_text_uk: Альтернатива: річ стає підметом і вживаємо to/for: The job was offered to me. The money was paid to her.
rule_short_en: Thing-first passive: ... was given to me.
rule_short_uk: Пасив з річчю: ... was given to me.
examples: The keys were handed to the guard.
A message was sent to me.

rule_text_en: Passive -ing form: being + past participle (I don't like being told what to do).
rule_text_uk: Пасивна форма -ing: being + дієприкметник (I don't like being told what to do).
examples: I hate being interrupted.
She remembers being asked that question.
He enjoys being praised.

rule_text_en: Structure 1: It is said/believed/known that + clause. It reports what people say or think.
rule_text_uk: Структура 1: It is said/believed/known that + підрядне. Передає, що кажуть або вважають люди.
examples: It is believed that the planet has water.
It is reported that the road is closed.

rule_text_en: Structure 2: He/She is said/believed/expected to + infinitive. Often more natural than 'It is said that...'.
rule_text_uk: Структура 2: He/She is said/believed/expected to + інфінітив. Часто звучить природніше за 'It is said that...'.
rule_short_en: He is said to ... / is expected to ...
rule_short_uk: He is said to ... / is expected to ...
examples: George is said to be 108.
The strike is expected to end soon.
The suspect is believed to live nearby.

rule_text_en: For the past: is said to have + past participle (He is alleged to have stolen a car).
rule_text_uk: Для минулого: is said to have + дієприкметник (He is alleged to have stolen a car).
rule_short_en: Past report: is said to have done.
rule_short_uk: Про минуле: is said to have done.
examples: She is thought to have left early.
He is believed to have lied.

rule_text_en: be supposed to = expected/should: You are supposed to lock the door. It can also mean 'it is said/assumed': The train is supposed to be on time.
rule_text_uk: be supposed to = очікується/слід: You are supposed to lock the door. Також може означати 'кажуть/вважають': The train is supposed to be on time.
examples: You're supposed to show your ID.
The museum is supposed to open at 10.

rule_text_en: have something done = arrange for someone else to do it: I had my car serviced.
rule_text_uk: have something done = домовитися, щоб хтось інший це зробив: I had my car serviced.
rule_short_en: Arrange a service: have something done.
rule_short_uk: Домовитися про послугу: have something done.
examples: I had my hair cut yesterday.
We are having the kitchen painted.
She had her phone repaired.

rule_text_en: get something done is similar to have something done, often more informal: get the roof repaired.
rule_text_uk: get something done схоже на have something done, часто більш розмовне: get the roof repaired.
rule_short_en: get something done = have something done.
rule_short_uk: get something done = have something done.
examples: I need to get my passport renewed.
He's getting the window fixed.

rule_text_en: have something done can also mean something bad happened to you/your things (not arranged): They had their bags stolen.
rule_text_uk: have something done також може означати, що з вами/вашими речами сталося щось погане (не ви організували): They had their bags stolen.
examples: He had his phone stolen on the bus.
She had her nose broken in a fight.

rule_text_en: Word order: have + object + past participle. In questions: How often do you have your car serviced? (not have serviced your car).
rule_text_uk: Порядок слів: have + об’єкт + дієприкметник. У питаннях: How often do you have your car serviced? (не have serviced your car).
examples: How often do you have your eyes tested?
Did you have it repaired?

rule_text_en: Reported speech: say/tell + (that) + clause. We often use a past reporting verb: Paul said (that) he was ill.
rule_text_uk: Непряма мова: say/tell + (that) + підрядне. Часто дієслово повідомлення в Past: Paul said (that) he was ill.
examples: Paul said he was tired.
I told her I was busy.
She said that she liked the film.

rule_text_en: Backshift: present → past (am→was, will→would, can→could).
rule_text_uk: Зсув часу: теперішній → минулий (am→was, will→would, can→could).
examples: He said, 'I am hungry.' → He said he was hungry.
She said, 'I will call.' → She said she would call.

rule_text_en: Past simple in direct speech can stay past simple, or change to past perfect when you want to show 'earlier': said he did / said he had done.
rule_text_uk: Past Simple у прямій мові може лишатися Past Simple або змінюватися на Past Perfect, щоб показати 'раніше': said he did / said he had done.
rule_short_en: Past simple may stay or become past perfect.
rule_short_uk: Past Simple може лишатися або стати Past Perfect.
examples: He said, 'I lost my keys.' → He said he lost / had lost his keys.
She said she met / had met him before.

rule_text_en: If the situation is still true/unchanged, you can keep the present in reported speech: Paul said his job is boring. You can also backshift.
rule_text_uk: Якщо ситуація досі актуальна, можна залишити Present: Paul said his job is boring. Також можна зробити зсув у Past.
rule_short_en: If still true, present can stay.
rule_short_uk: Якщо досі правда, Present може лишатися.
examples: Helen told me she wants to travel next year.
Paul said the weather is awful.

rule_text_en: say vs tell: say (that) ..., say something to somebody; tell somebody (that) ... (not 'said me').
rule_text_uk: say vs tell: say (that) ..., say something to somebody; tell somebody (that) ... (не 'said me').
examples: She told me she was late.
He said goodbye to me.
What did you say to the police?

rule_text_en: tell/ask somebody to do something for instructions and requests: The doctor told me to drink water. I asked him to slow down.
rule_text_uk: tell/ask somebody to do something для інструкцій і прохань: The doctor told me to drink water. I asked him to slow down.
examples: She told me to sit down.
I asked them to be quiet.

rule_text_en: Use the past in reported speech when what was said is no longer true or is clearly false: Rachel said you were in hospital (but you aren't).
rule_text_uk: Вживай Past у непрямій мові, якщо сказане вже не є правдою або очевидно хибне: Rachel said you were in hospital (але ти не там).
rule_short_en: Use past when the report is not true now.
rule_short_uk: Past — коли зараз це не правда.
examples: He said he had to go (and he left).
She said it was raining, but it wasn't.

rule_text_en: In most questions, the subject comes after the first verb: Are you ready? What time is it?
rule_text_uk: У більшості питань підмет стоїть після першого дієслова: Are you ready? What time is it?
rule_short_en: Question word order: verb before subject.
rule_short_uk: Порядок слів у питанні: дієслово перед підметом.
examples: Where are you going?
Can Tom drive?
What are they doing?

rule_text_en: With present simple and past simple, use do/does/did: Do you work here? Did she call?
rule_text_uk: У Present Simple та Past Simple використовуй do/does/did: Do you work here? Did she call?
examples: Does he live near here?
Did they sell the car?
Do you like coffee?

rule_text_en: No do/does/did when who/what is the subject: Who called you? (not Who did call).
rule_text_uk: Не використовуй do/does/did, коли who/what є підметом: Who called you? (не Who did call).
examples: Who broke the glass?
What happened?
Who wants tea?

rule_text_en: Question with preposition: often the preposition goes at the end: Who are you talking to? What are you looking for?
rule_text_uk: Питання з прийменником: часто прийменник наприкінці: Who are you talking to? What are you looking for?
rule_short_en: Prepositions often go at the end.
examples: Who did you speak to?
What are you waiting for?

rule_text_en: Indirect questions use statement word order: Do you know where Tom has gone? (not where has Tom gone).
rule_text_uk: Непрямі питання мають порядок слів як у твердженні: Do you know where Tom has gone? (не where has Tom gone).
rule_short_uk: Непряме питання: порядок як у твердженні.
examples: Could you tell me where the station is?
I don't know what time it is.

rule_text_en: In indirect questions with do/does/did, we drop do/does/did: Do you know what time the film starts? (not does it start).
rule_text_uk: У непрямих питаннях з do/does/did ми їх прибираємо: Do you know what time the film starts? (не does it start).
examples: Can you tell me where she lives?
I wonder why he left.

rule_text_en: Reported questions: He asked me where I lived / what I wanted. Use statement order and often backshift.
rule_text_uk: Передані питання: He asked me where I lived / what I wanted. Порядок слів як у твердженні, часто зі зсувом у Past.
examples: She asked me what I was doing.
They asked where we had been.

rule_text_en: Yes/no indirect questions use if or whether: Do you know if he is coming? She asked whether I could help.
rule_text_uk: Непрямі yes/no питання: if або whether: Do you know if he is coming? She asked whether I could help.
examples: I don't know if it's open.
He asked whether I had paid.

rule_text_en: Auxiliary verbs (have/do/can/be etc.) can stand before the main verb. We can repeat only the auxiliary to avoid repeating the full verb phrase.
rule_text_uk: Допоміжні дієслова (have/do/can/be тощо) стоять перед основним. Щоб не повторювати всю дієслівну фразу, часто повторюють лише допоміжне дієслово.
rule_short_en: Repeat the auxiliary to avoid repeating the verb phrase.
rule_short_uk: Повторюй допоміжне дієслово, щоб не повторювати всю фразу.
examples: ‘Have you finished?’ ‘Yes, I have.’
‘She can’t drive, but her brother can.’
‘Are they coming?’ ‘They are.’

rule_text_en: Use do/does/did as auxiliaries for present and past simple in short answers and questions.
rule_text_uk: У present і past simple як допоміжні в коротких відповідях і питаннях використовують do/does/did.
rule_short_en: Use do/does/did for short answers in present/past simple.
rule_short_uk: У present/past simple в коротких відповідях використовуй do/does/did.
examples: ‘Do you work here?’ ‘Yes, I do.’
‘Did he call?’ ‘No, he didn’t.’

rule_text_en: We can use an auxiliary alone to contradict or deny: ‘I’m not.’ ‘I did.’ ‘He hasn’t.’
rule_text_uk: Окреме допоміжне дієслово використовують, щоб заперечити/спростувати: ‘I’m not.’ ‘I did.’ ‘He hasn’t.’
rule_short_en: Use an auxiliary alone to deny or correct what someone says.
rule_short_uk: Окреме допоміжне дієслово: щоб заперечити або виправити сказане.
examples: ‘You were late.’ ‘No, I wasn’t.’
‘You didn’t pay.’ ‘Yes, I did.’

rule_text_en: We use question-like replies with an auxiliary (Have you? Is she? Did they?) to show interest or surprise about what someone said.
rule_text_uk: Питальні репліки з допоміжним (Have you? Is she? Did they?) показують зацікавлення або здивування щодо сказаного.
rule_short_en: Reply with ‘Have you?/Is she?/Did they?’ to show interest or surprise.
rule_short_uk: Репліки ‘Have you?/Is she?/Did they?’ виражають інтерес або здивування.
examples: ‘I’ve just met your sister.’ ‘Have you? What’s she like?’
‘We’re moving next month.’ ‘Are you? Where to?’

rule_text_en: With so/neither to agree, we invert: so + auxiliary + subject / neither + auxiliary + subject.
rule_text_uk: З so/neither для згоди робимо інверсію: so + допоміжне + підмет / neither + допоміжне + підмет.
examples: ‘I’m tired.’ ‘So am I.’
‘I can’t swim.’ ‘Neither can I.’

rule_text_en: Instead of neither, we can use nor. In negative answers we can also say not … either / I don’t either.
rule_text_uk: Замість neither можна вживати nor. У заперечних відповідях також можливе not … either / I don’t either.
rule_short_en: Alternatives: nor; not … either; I don’t either.
rule_short_uk: Варіанти: nor; not … either; I don’t either.
examples: ‘I don’t know.’ ‘Nor do I.’
‘I didn’t go.’ ‘I didn’t either.’

rule_text_en: We can answer without repeating: I think so / I suppose so / I expect so / I hope so / I’m afraid so.
rule_text_uk: Можна відповідати без повторення: I think so / I suppose so / I expect so / I hope so / I’m afraid so.
rule_short_en: Short replies: I think so / I hope so / I’m afraid so.
rule_short_uk: Короткі відповіді: I think so / I hope so / I’m afraid so.
examples: ‘Will it be expensive?’ ‘I think so.’
‘Is he coming?’ ‘I hope so.’

rule_text_en: Negative forms: I don’t think so; I hope not; I guess not; I’m afraid not. (Not: I don’t hope so.)
rule_text_uk: Заперечення: I don’t think so; I hope not; I guess not; I’m afraid not. (Не кажемо: I don’t hope so.)
rule_short_en: Negative replies: I don’t think so / I hope not / I’m afraid not.
rule_short_uk: Заперечні відповіді: I don’t think so / I hope not / I’m afraid not.
examples: ‘Do you think she knows?’ ‘I don’t think so.’
‘Will it rain?’ ‘I hope not.’

rule_text_en: Question tags are short questions at the end of a sentence. Use an auxiliary (have/be/will etc.), or do/does/did with present/past simple.
rule_text_uk: Question tags — це короткі питання в кінці речення. Використовуй допоміжне (have/be/will тощо) або do/does/did з present/past simple.
rule_short_en: Question tags: auxiliary + pronoun at the end of the sentence.
rule_short_uk: Question tags: допоміжне + займенник у кінці речення.
examples: You’ve met Anna, haven’t you?
Tom plays tennis, doesn’t he?

rule_text_en: Usually: positive sentence + negative tag; negative sentence + positive tag. After a negative statement, yes/no answers can be confusing, so match the meaning, not the word.
rule_text_uk: Зазвичай: ствердження + заперечний tag; заперечення + стверджувальний tag. Після заперечного речення yes/no треба узгоджувати зі змістом, а не зі словом.
examples: It’s cold today, isn’t it?
You don’t know her, do you?

rule_text_en: If your voice goes down, the tag asks for agreement (not a real question). If your voice goes up, it’s a real question (you want information).
rule_text_uk: Якщо інтонація падає, tag просить згоди (не справжнє питання). Якщо інтонація піднімається, це справжнє питання (потрібна інформація).
rule_short_en: Intonation: falling = agreement; rising = real question.
rule_short_uk: Інтонація: вниз = згода; вгору = справжнє питання.
examples: Nice weather, isn’t it? (agreement)
You haven’t seen my keys, have you? (real question)

rule_text_en: Negative sentence + positive tag can be used to ask for information or a favour: ‘You could help me, could you?’
rule_text_uk: Заперечне речення + стверджувальний tag часто вживають для прохання або уточнення: ‘You could help me, could you?’
rule_short_en: Use tags to ask for information or a favour.
examples: You don’t know his number, do you?
You could open the window, could you?

rule_text_en: Special tags: after Let’s…, use shall we? After Don’t…, use will you? After I’m…, the negative tag is aren’t I?
rule_text_uk: Особливі tags: після Let’s… — shall we? Після Don’t… — will you? Після I’m… заперечний tag — aren’t I?
rule_short_en: Special tags: Let’s… shall we? / Don’t… will you? / I’m… aren’t I?
rule_short_uk: Особливі tags: Let’s… shall we? / Don’t… will you? / I’m… aren’t I?
examples: Let’s go for a walk, shall we?
Don’t be late, will you?
I’m early, aren’t I?

rule_text_en: After some verbs (enjoy, mind, suggest etc.) we use verb + -ing, not to + infinitive. The negative is not + -ing.
rule_text_uk: Після деяких дієслів (enjoy, mind, suggest тощо) вживаємо дієслово з -ing, а не to + інфінітив. Заперечення: not + -ing.
examples: I enjoy reading in bed.
Would you mind waiting a minute?
She suggested meeting earlier.

rule_text_en: Many verbs are followed by -ing (stop, finish, avoid, consider, imagine, recommend, admit, deny, risk, fancy).
rule_text_uk: Багато дієслів вимагають -ing (stop, finish, avoid, consider, imagine, recommend, admit, deny, risk, fancy).
rule_short_en: Some verbs must be followed by -ing.
examples: He avoided answering my question.
They admitted taking the money.

rule_text_en: We use -ing after some phrasal verbs: give up, put off, go on / carry on, keep (on).
rule_text_uk: Після деяких фразових дієслів вживаємо -ing: give up, put off, go on / carry on, keep (on).
rule_short_en: Phrasal verbs like give up / put off / go on take -ing.
rule_short_uk: Phrasal дієслова give up / put off / go on вимагають -ing.
examples: I gave up drinking coffee.
Don’t put off doing your homework.

rule_text_en: With some verbs we can use verb + somebody + -ing (stop somebody doing, remember somebody saying, keep somebody waiting).
rule_text_uk: З деякими дієсловами можливе verb + somebody + -ing (stop somebody doing, remember somebody saying, keep somebody waiting).
examples: Please stop the kids shouting.
I remember him telling me that.

rule_text_en: With admit/deny/suggest/recommend, other structures are also possible (that-clause, etc.), not only -ing.
rule_text_uk: З admit/deny/suggest/recommend можливі й інші структури (that-clause тощо), не лише -ing.
rule_short_en: With admit/deny/suggest/recommend, other patterns are possible too.
rule_short_uk: З admit/deny/suggest/recommend можливі й інші моделі.
examples: They denied that they had done it.
I recommend that you take the train.

rule_text_en: After many verbs (decide, plan, promise, learn, manage etc.) we use to + infinitive: decide to go, promise to call.
rule_text_uk: Після багатьох дієслів (decide, plan, promise, learn, manage тощо) вживаємо to + інфінітив: decide to go, promise to call.
rule_short_en: Many verbs are followed by to + infinitive (decide to…, promise to…).
examples: We decided to leave early.
She promised to call me.

rule_text_en: The negative is not to + infinitive: decided not to go, promised not to tell.
rule_text_uk: Заперечення: not to + інфінітив: decided not to go, promised not to tell.
examples: He agreed not to mention it.
I chose not to buy it.

rule_text_en: After dare, we can use (to) + infinitive: dare to ask / dare ask. But after dare not / daren’t, we use the infinitive without to.
rule_text_uk: Після dare можливий інфінітив з to або без: dare to ask / dare ask. Але після dare not / daren’t — без to.
rule_short_en: After dare: (to) do; after daren’t: do (no to).
rule_short_uk: Після dare: (to) do; після daren’t: do (без to).
examples: I didn’t dare (to) interrupt.
I daren’t tell him.

rule_text_en: After seem/appear/pretend/claim we use to + infinitive: seem to know, pretend not to see.
rule_text_uk: Після seem/appear/pretend/claim вживаємо to + інфінітив: seem to know, pretend not to see.
examples: She seemed to understand.
He pretended not to notice.

rule_text_en: We can use to be -ing (continuous infinitive) or to have done (perfect infinitive): seem to be sleeping; claim to have lost it.
