rule_text_uk: Можна вживати to be -ing (continuous infinitive) або to have done (perfect infinitive): seem to be sleeping; claim to have lost it.
rule_short_en: Use to be -ing / to have done after seem/claim etc.
rule_short_uk: Після seem/claim тощо: to be -ing / to have done.
examples: They seemed to be waiting for us.
She claimed to have seen it.

rule_text_en: After question words we use (what/how/where etc.) + to + infinitive: decide what to do; show me how to use it.
rule_text_uk: Після питальних слів вживаємо (what/how/where тощо) + to + інфінітив: decide what to do; show me how to use it.
rule_short_en: Question word + to + infinitive: what to do, how to get there.
rule_short_uk: Питальне слово + to + інфінітив: what to do, how to get there.
examples: I don’t know what to say.
Can you show me how to start it?

rule_text_en: Some verbs can be followed by to + infinitive with or without an object: want (to go / you to go), expect, ask, would like, would prefer.
rule_text_uk: Деякі дієслова можуть мати to-інфінітив з додатком або без: want (to go / you to go), expect, ask, would like, would prefer.
rule_short_en: Want/expect/ask etc.: to… or object + to…
rule_short_uk: Want/expect/ask тощо: to… або object + to…
examples: I want to leave now.
I want you to leave now.

rule_text_en: Help can be used with or without to: help me (to) carry this.
rule_text_uk: Після help можливий інфінітив з to або без: help me (to) carry this.
examples: Can you help me (to) move this chair?
They helped us (to) find the address.

rule_text_en: Some verbs need an object before to + infinitive: tell/advise/remind/warn/invite/encourage/persuade/allow etc.
rule_text_uk: Деякі дієслова потребують додатка перед to-інфінітивом: tell/advise/remind/warn/invite/encourage/persuade/allow тощо.
examples: She reminded me to call.
They warned us not to touch it.

rule_text_en: In the passive we use be + past participle + to: be allowed to…, be warned to…, be invited to…
rule_text_uk: У пасиві: be + дієприкметник минулого + to: be allowed to…, be warned to…, be invited to…
examples: We were allowed to enter.
He was warned not to drive.

rule_text_en: Make/let are followed by the infinitive without to: make somebody do, let somebody do.
rule_text_uk: Після make/let вживаємо інфінітив без to: make somebody do, let somebody do.
examples: The joke made me laugh.
Her parents don’t let her stay out late.

rule_text_en: In the passive, make becomes be made to: We were made to wait. (to is used in the passive.)
rule_text_uk: У пасиві з make: be made to: We were made to wait. (У пасиві з’являється to.)
examples: I was made to apologise.
They were made to leave early.

rule_text_en: Some verbs are followed by -ing (enjoy, avoid, suggest…), and some by to + infinitive (decide, promise, manage…). Learn which pattern each verb takes.
rule_text_uk: Деякі дієслова вимагають -ing (enjoy, avoid, suggest…), а деякі — to + інфінітив (decide, promise, manage…). Треба запам’ятати, яку модель має кожне дієслово.
rule_short_en: Some verbs take -ing; others take to + infinitive.
rule_short_uk: Одні дієслова вимагають -ing, інші — to + інфінітив.
examples: He suggested meeting at six.
She decided to leave early.

rule_text_en: Remember: remember doing = you did it and you remember it now. Remember to do = don’t forget to do it (a duty in the future).
rule_text_uk: Remember: remember doing = ти це зробив і зараз пам’ятаєш. Remember to do = не забудь це зробити (обов’язок у майбутньому).
rule_short_en: Remember doing = past memory; remember to do = don’t forget a duty.
rule_short_uk: Remember doing = спогад; remember to do = не забути зробити.
examples: I remember meeting her once.
Remember to lock the door.

rule_text_en: Regret doing = you did it and you feel sorry now. Regret to say/tell/inform = formal: you are sorry about what you must say.
rule_text_uk: Regret doing = ти це зробив і тепер шкодуєш. Regret to say/tell/inform = формально: шкода повідомляти те, що мусиш сказати.
rule_short_en: Regret doing vs regret to say (formal).
rule_short_uk: Regret doing vs regret to say (формально).
examples: I regret buying it.
We regret to inform you that…

rule_text_en: Go on doing = continue the same activity. Go on to do = do something new next.
rule_text_uk: Go on doing = продовжувати ту саму дію. Go on to do = потім перейти до нової дії.
rule_short_en: Go on doing = continue; go on to do = do next.
rule_short_uk: Go on doing = продовжувати; go on to do = потім зробити інше.
examples: He went on talking for hours.
She finished her degree and went on to work abroad.

rule_text_en: Begin/start/continue/intend/bother can be followed by -ing or to + infinitive with little or no change in meaning.
rule_text_uk: Після begin/start/continue/intend/bother можливі -ing або to + інфінітив майже без різниці в значенні.
rule_short_uk: Begin/start/continue/intend/bother: -ing або to + інфінітив (значення майже те саме).
examples: It started raining / to rain.
I don’t intend to stay long / staying long.

rule_text_en: After start (meaning ‘begin’), we normally say starting to…, not starting -ing: It’s starting to rain.
rule_text_uk: Після start у значенні ‘починатися’ зазвичай кажуть starting to…, а не starting -ing: It’s starting to rain.
rule_short_en: Usually: It’s starting to…, not starting -ing.
rule_short_uk: Зазвичай: It’s starting to…, не starting -ing.
examples: It’s starting to get dark.
It’s starting to rain.

rule_text_en: Try to do = attempt / make an effort. Try doing = do it as an experiment to see if it helps.
rule_text_uk: Try to do = спробувати (докласти зусиль). Try doing = спробувати як експеримент, щоб подивитися, чи допоможе.
rule_short_en: Try to do = attempt; try doing = experiment.
rule_short_uk: Try to do = спроба/зусилля; try doing = експеримент.
examples: I tried to lift it, but it was too heavy.
Try pressing this button.

rule_text_en: Need to do means ‘it is necessary for someone to do it’. Need -ing means ‘it needs to be done’ (passive meaning).
rule_text_uk: Need to do означає ‘треба зробити’. Need -ing означає ‘потрібно, щоб це зробили’ (пасивне значення).
rule_short_en: Need to do = necessary; need -ing = needs to be done.
rule_short_uk: Need to do = потрібно; need -ing = треба зробити (пасивно).
examples: I need to charge my phone.
My phone needs charging.

rule_text_en: Help can be followed by (to) + infinitive: help (to) carry, help (to) clean.
rule_text_uk: Після help можливе (to) + інфінітив: help (to) carry, help (to) clean.
examples: Can you help me (to) move this?
They helped clean up after the party.

rule_text_en: Can’t help doing = can’t stop yourself from doing it. You can also say can’t help it (= can’t help being…).
rule_text_uk: Can’t help doing = не можеш утриматися від цього. Також: can’t help it (= can’t help being…).
rule_short_en: Can’t help doing = can’t stop yourself.
rule_short_uk: Can’t help doing = не можеш стриматися.
examples: She couldn’t help laughing.
I can’t help it. I’m nervous.

rule_text_en: With like/love/hate in general (repeated actions), we can use -ing or to + infinitive: like swimming / like to swim.
rule_text_uk: З like/love/hate у загальному значенні (звичні дії) можна вживати -ing або to + інфінітив: like swimming / like to swim.
examples: I like reading in the evening.
I like to read before bed.

rule_text_en: We use -ing (not to…) when we talk about a situation that already exists/existed: likes living here; hated working there.
rule_text_uk: Вживаємо -ing (не to…), коли говоримо про вже існуючу/минулу ситуацію: likes living here; hated working there.
rule_short_en: -ing for an existing situation: likes living…, hated working…
rule_short_uk: -ing для вже існуючої ситуації: likes living…, hated working…
examples: He likes living near the sea.
I hated working in that office.

rule_text_en: Sometimes there’s a difference: like doing = enjoy it; like to do = choose to do it (maybe not enjoyable).
rule_text_uk: Іноді є різниця: like doing = подобається (насолоджуюся); like to do = роблю за вибором/звичкою (може й не подобатися).
rule_short_en: Like doing = enjoy; like to do = choose/habit.
rule_short_uk: Like doing = насолода; like to do = вибір/звичка.
examples: I like cooking. (I enjoy it.)
I like to cook early, before it gets busy. (habit/choice)

rule_text_en: Would like / would love / would hate / would prefer are usually followed by to + infinitive. Would mind is followed by -ing.
rule_text_uk: Would like / would love / would hate / would prefer зазвичай мають to + інфінітив. Would mind вимагає -ing.
examples: I’d like to go for a walk.
Would you mind closing the door?

rule_text_en: Would like to have done = you regret now that you didn’t do it (or couldn’t): I’d like to have seen her again.
rule_text_uk: Would like to have done = зараз шкодуєш, що не зробив (або не міг): I’d like to have seen her again.
rule_short_en: Would like to have done = regret about the past.
rule_short_uk: Would like to have done = жаль щодо минулого.
examples: I’d like to have gone with you, but I was ill.
She’d hate to have missed the concert.

rule_text_en: Prefer can be followed by to + infinitive or -ing for general preference: prefer to stay / prefer staying.
rule_text_uk: Prefer може мати to + інфінітив або -ing для загальної переваги: prefer to stay / prefer staying.
examples: I prefer to live outside the city.
I prefer living outside the city.

rule_text_en: We can say prefer X to Y, prefer doing X to doing Y, or prefer to do X rather than (do) Y.
rule_text_uk: Можна: prefer X to Y, prefer doing X to doing Y або prefer to do X rather than (do) Y.
rule_short_en: Prefer X to Y / prefer doing X to doing Y / prefer to do X rather than Y.
rule_short_uk: Prefer X to Y / prefer doing X to doing Y / prefer to do X rather than Y.
examples: I prefer tea to coffee.
I prefer driving to taking the train.
I prefer to walk rather than take a taxi.

rule_text_en: Would prefer (I’d prefer…) is for a specific situation. We normally say would prefer to do (not would prefer doing).
rule_text_uk: Would prefer (I’d prefer…) — для конкретної ситуації. Зазвичай: would prefer to do (не would prefer doing).
examples: I’d prefer to stay home tonight.
Would you prefer tea or coffee?

rule_text_en: Would rather (I’d rather…) is followed by the base verb (no to): I’d rather go / I’d rather not go. We can also use rather … than …
rule_text_uk: Would rather (I’d rather…) вимагає основу дієслова (без to): I’d rather go / I’d rather not go. Також: rather … than …
rule_short_en: Would rather + base verb (no to); negative: would rather not.
rule_short_uk: Would rather + основа дієслова (без to); заперечення: would rather not.
examples: I’d rather walk than take the bus.
I’d rather not go out tonight.

rule_text_en: We can say I’d rather you did/didn’t… (past form) to mean a present preference about another person’s action.
rule_text_uk: Можна: I’d rather you did/didn’t… (форма минулого) — теперішня перевага щодо дій іншої людини.
rule_short_en: I’d rather you did/didn’t… = preference about someone else (present meaning).
rule_short_uk: I’d rather you did/didn’t… = перевага щодо іншої людини (значення теперішнє).
examples: I’d rather you didn’t tell anyone.
Would you rather I waited here?

rule_text_en: After a preposition (in/for/about/of/with etc.), use verb + -ing: interested in doing, good at doing, tired of waiting.
rule_text_uk: Після прийменника (in/for/about/of/with тощо) вживаємо дієслово з -ing: interested in doing, good at doing, tired of waiting.
examples: I’m interested in learning Spanish.
She’s good at solving problems.
Thanks for coming.

rule_text_en: We say before + -ing and after + -ing: Before leaving, I called her. After finishing, we went home.
rule_text_uk: Вживаємо before + -ing і after + -ing: Before leaving, I called her. After finishing, we went home.
examples: Before going out, lock the door.
What did you do after arriving?

rule_text_en: By + -ing describes how something happens: improve by practising; solve it by talking.
rule_text_uk: By + -ing описує, як щось відбувається: improve by practising; solve it by talking.
examples: He learned faster by practising every day.
She opened it by turning the key.

rule_text_en: Without + -ing means ‘without doing it’: drove home without stopping. We can also use without being + past participle.
rule_text_uk: Without + -ing означає ‘не роблячи’: drove home without stopping. Також можливе without being + дієприкметник.
examples: They left without saying goodbye.
I can’t work without being interrupted.

rule_text_en: To can be an infinitive marker (to do), but it can also be a preposition (similar to in/for). When it’s a preposition, use to + -ing.
rule_text_uk: To може бути часткою інфінітива (to do), але також буває прийменником (як in/for). Коли to — прийменник, далі йде to + -ing.
rule_short_en: To is sometimes a preposition → to + -ing.
examples: I’m looking forward to seeing you.
I prefer walking to driving.

rule_text_en: Many verbs are followed by to + infinitive (want, decide, hope, plan).
rule_text_uk: Багато дієслів уживаються з to + інфінітивом (want, decide, hope, plan).
examples: I want to leave early.
She decided to study medicine.
We hope to see you soon.

rule_text_en: Some verbs can be followed by question words + to (what to do, how to get there).
rule_text_uk: Деякі дієслова можуть мати після себе питальне слово + to (what to do, how to get there).
examples: I don’t know what to say.
Can you show me how to use it?
She asked where to park.

rule_text_en: After would like / would love / would prefer we use to + infinitive.
rule_text_uk: Після would like / would love / would prefer уживаємо to + інфінітив.
examples: I’d like to speak to the manager.
We’d love to come.
I’d prefer to stay at home.

rule_text_en: Some verbs are followed by -ing (enjoy, mind, avoid, finish).
rule_text_uk: Після деяких дієслів уживаємо -ing (enjoy, mind, avoid, finish).
examples: I enjoy reading in bed.
Do you mind waiting?
He avoided talking about it.

rule_text_en: After prepositions we normally use -ing: interested in doing, good at doing.
rule_text_uk: Після прийменників зазвичай -ing: interested in doing, good at doing.
examples: She’s interested in learning Spanish.
I’m good at remembering names.
They left without saying goodbye.

rule_text_en: Go + -ing is used for activities: go shopping, go swimming, go running.
rule_text_uk: Go + -ing уживають для занять: go shopping, go swimming, go running.
examples: Let’s go swimming.
We went shopping yesterday.
He goes running every morning.

rule_text_en: Some verbs take an object + to + infinitive: want/ask/tell/expect someone to do.
rule_text_uk: Деякі дієслова мають додаток + to + інфінітив: want/ask/tell/expect someone to do.
examples: I want you to listen.
She told him to wait.
We expect them to arrive soon.

rule_text_en: Some verbs use object + infinitive without to (make/let/help in some patterns).
rule_text_uk: З деякими дієсловами інфінітив без to: make/let (інколи help).
examples: They made me apologise.
Let me explain.
This will help you (to) understand.

rule_text_en: Ask/tell/order/advise + object + to is common in requests and instructions.
rule_text_uk: Ask/tell/order/advise + додаток + to часто вживають у проханнях та інструкціях.
examples: I asked her to call me.
Tell them to be quiet.
The doctor advised me to rest.

rule_text_en: Some verbs can be followed by -ing or to with a change in meaning (stop, remember, try).
rule_text_uk: Деякі дієслова можуть мати -ing або to з різницею значення (stop, remember, try).
examples: Stop smoking. (stop the habit)
Stop to smoke. (stop in order to smoke)
Remember to lock the door.

rule_text_en: Remember/forget + to = do it; remember/forget + -ing = memory of a past action.
rule_text_uk: Remember/forget + to = зробити; remember/forget + -ing = спогад про минулу дію.
rule_short_en: Remember to do vs remember doing.
rule_short_uk: Пам’ятати зробити vs пам’ятати, що робив.
examples: I remembered to call her.
I remember meeting her before.
Don’t forget to pay.

rule_text_en: Try + to = attempt; try + -ing = experiment to see what happens.
rule_text_uk: Try + to = спробувати (зусилля); try + -ing = спробувати як експеримент.
rule_short_en: Try to do vs try doing.
examples: I tried to open the window.
Try restarting your phone.
He tried talking to her calmly.

rule_text_en: We use to + infinitive to say the purpose: I went out to buy food.
rule_text_uk: To + інфінітив уживають, щоб показати мету: I went out to buy food.
examples: I came here to ask a question.
She called to apologise.
We stopped to get petrol.

rule_text_en: In order to / so as to are more formal ways to express purpose; negatives: in order not to / so as not to.
rule_text_uk: In order to / so as to — більш офіційно для мети; заперечення: in order not to / so as not to.
examples: He spoke quietly in order not to wake the baby.
I moved closer so as to hear better.
She left early in order to catch the train.

rule_text_en: For + noun can express purpose (a thing): a tool for cutting, a room for meetings.
rule_text_uk: For + іменник може виражати призначення: a tool for cutting, a room for meetings.
rule_short_en: For + noun = purpose of a thing.
examples: This key is for the back door.
A cup is for drinking.
We need a place for parking.

rule_text_en: After some adjectives we use to + infinitive: easy to do, difficult to understand, happy to help.
rule_text_uk: Після деяких прикметників уживаємо to + інфінітив: easy to do, difficult to understand, happy to help.
examples: It’s easy to make.
I’m happy to help.
This is hard to explain.

rule_text_en: We often use it + adjective + to: It’s nice to see you. It was impossible to park.
rule_text_uk: Часто вживаємо it + прикметник + to: It’s nice to see you. It was impossible to park.
examples: It’s good to hear that.
It’s dangerous to drive fast.
It was silly to argue.

rule_text_en: With adjectives like surprised/glad/sorry, we can use that-clause or to-clause: I’m glad to see you / glad that you came.
rule_text_uk: З прикметниками surprised/glad/sorry можливе that-підрядне або to: glad to see you / glad that you came.
examples: I’m glad to meet you.
I’m sorry to hear that.
She was surprised that he left.

rule_text_en: After prepositions we use -ing: before leaving, without saying, by doing.
rule_text_uk: Після прийменників уживаємо -ing: before leaving, without saying, by doing.
examples: Wash your hands before eating.
He left without paying.
You can improve by practising.

rule_text_en: Verb + preposition + -ing is common: apologise for doing, succeed in doing, insist on doing.
rule_text_uk: Поширено: дієслово + прийменник + -ing: apologise for doing, succeed in doing, insist on doing.
examples: They insisted on paying.
I apologise for being late.
He succeeded in passing.

rule_text_en: To is also a preposition in be used to / look forward to, so it is followed by -ing.
rule_text_uk: To також може бути прийменником у be used to / look forward to, тому після нього -ing.
rule_short_en: Be used to / look forward to + -ing.
rule_short_uk: Be used to / look forward to + -ing.
examples: I’m used to getting up early.
I look forward to seeing you.
She isn’t used to driving.

rule_text_en: We can use -ing as a subject: Swimming is good for you. Reading helps you relax.
rule_text_uk: -ing може бути підметом: Swimming is good for you. Reading helps you relax.
examples: Travelling teaches you a lot.
Smoking is bad for you.
Learning languages takes time.

rule_text_en: We can use -ing after be to talk about a job/activity: My hobby is collecting stamps.
rule_text_uk: -ing після be може описувати заняття/роботу: My hobby is collecting stamps.
examples: My job is teaching.
Her hobby is painting.
The best thing is getting started.

rule_text_en: After no point / worth / busy, we often use -ing: It’s worth doing. There’s no point arguing.
rule_text_uk: Після no point / worth / busy часто -ing: It’s worth doing. There’s no point arguing.
examples: It’s worth waiting.
There’s no point complaining.
I’m busy preparing for exams.

rule_text_en: Be used to means 'accustomed to' and is followed by a noun or -ing: I’m used to getting up early.
rule_text_uk: Be used to означає «звиклий» і має після себе іменник або -ing: I’m used to getting up early.
examples: I’m used to cold winters.
She’s used to working nights.
We’re not used to this noise.

rule_text_en: Get used to means 'become accustomed to' (a change over time).
rule_text_uk: Get used to означає «звикати» (процес).
examples: You’ll get used to the traffic.
He’s getting used to his new job.
It took me weeks to get used to it.

rule_text_en: Used to (without be/get) means a past habit/state: I used to live there. (different meaning).
rule_text_uk: Used to (без be/get) означає звичку/стан у минулому: I used to live there. (інше значення).
examples: I used to smoke.
She used to be shy.
We used to live in Odesa.

rule_text_en: Prefer can be followed by -ing or to + infinitive: I prefer walking / I prefer to walk.
rule_text_uk: Prefer може мати -ing або to + інфінітив: I prefer walking / I prefer to walk.
examples: I prefer tea to coffee.
She prefers to travel by train.
We prefer staying at home.

rule_text_en: Would rather + infinitive without to: I’d rather stay in. Negative: would rather not.
rule_text_uk: Would rather + інфінітив без to: I’d rather stay in. Заперечення: would rather not.
examples: I’d rather go now.
I’d rather not talk about it.
Would you rather sit here?

rule_text_en: Would rather + past (about someone else) for present/future: I’d rather you didn’t smoke.
rule_text_uk: Would rather + past (про іншу особу) для теперішнього/майбутнього: I’d rather you didn’t smoke.
rule_short_uk: Я б волів, щоб ти (не) робив…
examples: I’d rather you came earlier.
I’d rather he didn’t drive.
Would you rather I called later?

rule_text_en: Use a/an with singular countable nouns when we mean one thing (often for the first time).
rule_text_uk: Вживай a/an із злічуваними іменниками в однині, коли йдеться про одну річ (часто при першій згадці).
examples: I bought a new phone yesterday.
She’s reading an interesting book.
There’s a cat in the garden.

rule_text_en: Use some with plural countable nouns and with uncountable nouns when we mean ‘a quantity’ (not exact).
rule_text_uk: Вживай some зі злічуваними в множині та з незлічуваними, коли мається на увазі певна кількість (не точно).
examples: I need some eggs and some milk.
We bought some furniture for the flat.
He gave me some advice.

rule_text_en: Some is common in offers and requests: Would you like some…? Can I have some…?
rule_text_uk: Some часто вживається в пропозиціях і проханнях: Would you like some…? Can I have some…?
examples: Would you like some tea?
Can I have some water, please?
Let’s buy some bread.

rule_text_en: Use a/an when we mention something for the first time; use the when we mention the same thing again.
rule_text_uk: Вживай a/an, коли згадуєш щось уперше; вживай the, коли згадуєш це знову.
examples: I saw a dog. The dog was very friendly.
She bought a bag. The bag was expensive.
There was an email. The email was from my boss.

rule_text_en: Use the when the listener can identify which thing you mean (because it’s known from the situation or context).
rule_text_uk: Вживай the, коли співрозмовник може зрозуміти, про яку саме річ ідеться (відомо з ситуації/контексту).
examples: Could you close the window? (the one here)
I’ll meet you at the station.
Where’s the key?

rule_text_en: Use a/an when we mean ‘one of many’ and it doesn’t matter which one.
rule_text_uk: Вживай a/an, коли мається на увазі «один із багатьох» і не важливо який саме.
examples: I need a pen. (any pen)
She wants to buy a car. (not a particular one)
Let’s choose a restaurant.

rule_text_en: Use the for something unique (the sun, the equator) and with superlatives (the best, the longest).
rule_text_uk: Вживай the з унікальними речами (the sun, the equator) і з найвищим ступенем (the best, the longest).
examples: The moon looked bright tonight.
What’s the most expensive hotel here?
She lives on the top floor.

rule_text_en: The can mean a specific thing; a/an means one example. Sometimes the changes the meaning (space vs the space).
rule_text_uk: The може означати конкретну річ; a/an — один приклад. Іноді the змінює значення (space vs the space).
examples: A laptop is a tool; the laptop on the table is mine.
Space is huge. The space in my bag is small.
A river is long; the river here is polluted.

rule_text_en: We say the cinema/the theatre, the radio, the internet, but we usually say TV (without the).
rule_text_uk: Кажемо the cinema/the theatre, the radio, the internet, але зазвичай TV без the.
examples: We went to the cinema after work.
I listen to the radio in the car.
I watch TV most evenings.

rule_text_en: Without the: go to school/university etc. when we mean the activity (as a student).
rule_text_uk: Без the: go to school/university тощо, коли маємо на увазі процес/роль (як студент).
examples: My son goes to school nearby.
She is at university now.
He went to college in Canada.

rule_text_en: With the: the school/the university etc. when we mean the building or a particular place.
rule_text_uk: З the: the school/the university тощо, коли маємо на увазі будівлю або конкретне місце.
examples: I’ll meet you at the school gate.
The university is closed today.
She walked past the hospital.

rule_text_en: In common expressions we often say go home, be at work, go to bed (no the).
rule_text_uk: У сталих виразах часто кажемо go home, be at work, go to bed (без the).
rule_short_en: Fixed phrases: go home / to bed.
rule_short_uk: Сталi вирази: go home / to bed.
examples: I was tired, so I went to bed early.
He arrived home late.
She was at work all day.

rule_text_en: For things/people in general, use plural or uncountable nouns without the.
rule_text_uk: Коли говоримо загалом, вживаємо множину або незлічувані іменники без the.
examples: Dogs need exercise.
Music helps me concentrate.
Cars are expensive now.

rule_text_en: Even with a description, we can mean a general category: people who…, coffee with milk…, etc. (still no the).
rule_text_uk: Навіть з уточненням можна мати на увазі категорію загалом: people who…, coffee with milk… (все ще без the).
examples: I admire people who stay calm.
I don’t like food with too much salt.
She avoids drinks with sugar.

rule_text_en: Use the for a specific group/thing, often with extra information (the people I work with, the coffee we had).
rule_text_uk: Вживай the для конкретної групи/речі, часто з уточненням (the people I work with, the coffee we had).
examples: I like the people in my class.
The music you played was great.
The car we rented was tiny.

rule_text_en: We can use the + singular countable noun to talk about a type/species/invention (not one specific example).
rule_text_uk: Можна вживати the + злічуваний в однині, щоб говорити про тип/вид/винахід (не про конкретний екземпляр).
examples: The elephant is a very intelligent animal.
When was the bicycle invented?
The smartphone has changed communication.

rule_text_en: We normally use the with musical instruments: play the guitar/piano/violin etc.
rule_text_uk: З музичними інструментами зазвичай вживаємо the: play the guitar/piano/violin тощо.
examples: Can you play the piano?
She’s learning the violin.
He plays the drums in a band.

rule_text_en: We use the with some nationality words (the Swiss, the Portuguese). With others we use a plural -s (Italians).
rule_text_uk: З деякими назвами національностей вживаємо the (the Swiss, the Portuguese). З іншими — множину на -s (Italians).
examples: The Swiss are famous for watches.
Italians love good food.
The Portuguese speak Portuguese.

rule_text_en: We do not use the with most names of continents, countries, cities, islands and mountains.
rule_text_uk: З більшістю назв континентів, країн, міст, островів і гір the не вживається.
examples: France is in Europe.
Tokyo is very busy.
Everest is the highest mountain.

title_en: The with Republic/Kingdom/States and plural names
rule_text_en: We often use the in names with Republic/Kingdom/States etc. and with plural names (the United States, the Netherlands).
rule_text_uk: The часто вживається в назвах із Republic/Kingdom/States тощо та з назвами у множині (the United States, the Netherlands).
examples: They live in the United States.
I’d like to visit the Czech Republic.
The Netherlands is famous for canals.

title_en: North/south: in the south vs northern Spain
rule_text_en: We say in the north/south/east/west, but we usually say northern Spain / western Canada (no the).
rule_text_uk: Кажемо in the north/south/east/west, але зазвичай northern Spain / western Canada (без the).
examples: Spain is in the south of Europe.
They drove through northern Italy.
She lives in the west of the country.

rule_text_en: We usually don’t use the with names of streets, roads, squares and parks (Union Street, Hyde Park).
rule_text_uk: З назвами вулиць/доріг/площ/парків зазвичай не вживаємо the (Union Street, Hyde Park).
examples: We met on Baker Street.
They walked through Hyde Park.
The hotel is on Fifth Avenue.

title_en: Institutions named with place/person: usually no the
rule_text_en: Names like Manchester Airport or Harvard University are usually without the when the first word is a name.
rule_text_uk: Назви типу Manchester Airport або Harvard University зазвичай без the, якщо перше слово — назва місця/людини.
examples: She studies at Oxford University.
I arrived at Manchester Airport.
We changed trains at Victoria Station.

rule_text_en: Many newspapers and organisations use the: the BBC, the European Union, the Red Cross, the Times.
rule_text_uk: Багато газет і організацій вживають the: the BBC, the European Union, the Red Cross, the Times.
examples: I read the Financial Times online.
The BBC reported the story.
He works for the Red Cross.

rule_text_en: Company and airline names are usually without the (Sony, IBM, Singapore Airlines).
rule_text_uk: Назви компаній і авіаліній зазвичай без the (Sony, IBM, Singapore Airlines).
examples: IBM released a new product.
She flew with Singapore Airlines.
Sony makes cameras too.

rule_text_en: Words like trousers, glasses, scissors are plural and take a plural verb. You can say a pair of trousers/glasses etc.
rule_text_uk: Слова trousers, glasses, scissors — множинні й вимагають дієслово в множині. Можна сказати a pair of trousers/glasses тощо.
rule_short_en: Trousers are; a pair of trousers.
rule_short_uk: Trousers are; a pair of trousers.
examples: My jeans are too tight.
These scissors are sharp.
I bought a pair of sunglasses.

rule_text_en: Police is a plural word: The police are … . For one person we say a police officer.
rule_text_uk: Police — множинне слово: The police are … . Для однієї людини кажемо a police officer.
examples: The police are looking for a witness.
A police officer helped us.
The police have arrested someone.

rule_text_en: We usually use people as the plural of person (not persons in normal speech).
rule_text_uk: Зазвичай множина від person — people (не persons у звичайній мові).
examples: He’s a nice person.
They are nice people.
Many people travel for work.

rule_text_en: We treat sums of money, time and distance as one thing, so we often use a singular verb: Ten minutes is …
rule_text_uk: Суми грошей, час і відстань часто сприймаємо як одне ціле, тому часто вживаємо однину: Ten minutes is …
examples: Three hours is enough.
Two miles isn’t far.
Fifty dollars was stolen.

rule_text_en: Two nouns can go together to mean one thing (bus driver, city centre). The first noun describes the type.
rule_text_uk: Два іменники можуть утворювати одну назву (bus driver, city centre). Перший іменник описує тип.
rule_short_en: bus driver = driver of a bus.
examples: My brother is a taxi driver.
The city centre is crowded.
We pay income tax.

rule_text_en: The first noun can be a place/person: a Paris hotel, a Shakespeare play. It works like an adjective.
rule_text_uk: Першим іменником може бути назва місця/людини: a Paris hotel, a Shakespeare play. Він працює як прикметник.
rule_short_en: a Paris hotel; a Shakespeare play.
rule_short_uk: a Paris hotel; a Shakespeare play.
examples: We stayed in a London hotel.
I read a detective story.
She loves a Mozart concert.

rule_text_en: Measurements used as adjectives are singular and often hyphenated: a three-hour journey, a four-week course.
rule_text_uk: Міри як прикметники вживаються в однині й часто через дефіс: a three-hour journey, a four-week course.
examples: It was a ten-mile walk.
They took a two-week holiday.
We have a three-hour meeting.

rule_text_en: Use ’s to show that a person/animal/organisation owns or is linked to something (Sarah’s bike, the dog’s tail).
rule_text_uk: Використовуй ’s, щоб показати належність або зв’язок із людиною/твариною/організацією (Sarah’s bike тощо).
rule_short_uk: ’s показує належність/зв’язок із людьми, тваринами, організаціями.
examples: Tom's jacket is on the chair.
The cat's paw is hurt.
The company's website is down.

rule_text_en: With plural nouns ending in -s, put the apostrophe after s (my parents’ car). With irregular plurals, use ’s (children’s toys).
rule_text_uk: З множиною на -s апостроф ставиться після s (parents’). З неправильними множинами — ’s (children’s).
examples: The students' room is upstairs.
My friends' flat is small.
The children's games were noisy.

rule_text_en: We often use ’s with time/amount expressions: a week’s holiday, two hours’ work, ten minutes’ walk.
rule_text_uk: Часто вживаємо ’s із виразами часу/кількості: a week’s holiday, two hours’ work тощо.
rule_short_en: Use ’s for time/amount: a week’s, two hours’.
rule_short_uk: ’s для часу/кількості: a week’s, two hours’.
examples: We had a week's break.
It was two hours' work.
It's a ten minutes' walk from here.

rule_text_en: Use of with things/ideas, or when the ‘owner’ phrase is long: the roof of the house, the colour of the old sofa.
rule_text_uk: Вживай of із речами/ідеями або коли «власник» — довга фраза: the roof of the house тощо.
rule_short_en: Use of for things or long ‘owner’ phrases.
rule_short_uk: of — для речей або довгих фраз «власника».
examples: The handle of the suitcase broke.
The end of the film was surprising.
The name of the new café is hard to spell.

rule_text_en: Sometimes both patterns are possible; choose what sounds natural. With places/shops, ’s is common (the bakery’s window).
rule_text_uk: Іноді можливі обидва варіанти; обирай природніший. Із місцями/крамницями часто вживають ’s (the bakery’s window).
rule_short_en: Sometimes ’s or of; with places/shops, ’s is common.
rule_short_uk: Іноді ’s або of; із місцями/крамницями часто ’s.
examples: The hotel's lobby is bright.
The door of the garage is stuck.
The museum's entrance is on the left.

rule_text_en: Use reflexive pronouns (myself/yourself/himself etc.) when the subject and object are the same person.
rule_text_uk: Використовуй зворотні займенники (myself/yourself/himself тощо), коли підмет і додаток — одна й та сама особа.
examples: I cut myself while cooking.
She blamed herself for the mistake.
We introduced ourselves at the meeting.

rule_text_en: Some verbs are often used reflexively (get dressed, shave, wash). We usually say: get dressed / shave (not dress yourself).
rule_text_uk: Деякі дії часто описують без зворотного займенника: get dressed, shave, wash (частіше, ніж dress yourself).
examples: He got dressed quickly.
I usually shave before breakfast.
She washed and left the house.

rule_text_en: Use each other / one another when A does something to B and B does it to A: They help each other.
rule_text_uk: Вживай each other / one another, коли дія взаємна: A → B і B → A.
examples: They text each other every day.
We don't see each other often.
The twins always copy one another.

rule_text_en: We can use myself/yourself etc. to emphasise the subject: I made it myself (= not someone else). Also: the manager himself.
rule_text_uk: Можна вживати myself/yourself тощо для підсилення: I made it myself (= не хтось інший). Також: the manager himself.
rule_short_en: myself can emphasise: I did it myself.
rule_short_uk: myself підсилює: I did it myself.
examples: I repaired the chair myself.
The author herself replied.
The president himself opened the event.

rule_text_en: Use a friend of mine/yours/his etc. to mean ‘one of my/your/his friends’. Also: a picture of ours, a student of theirs.
rule_text_uk: Вживай a friend of mine/yours/his тощо = «один із моїх/твоїх/його друзів». Також: a picture of ours, a student of theirs.
rule_short_en: a friend of mine = one of my friends.
rule_short_uk: a friend of mine = один із моїх друзів.
examples: A neighbour of ours lent us a ladder.
A colleague of mine called this morning.
That idea of yours is interesting.

rule_text_en: Use my own/your own etc. to mean ‘belonging only to me/you’ or ‘not shared’: my own room, her own business.
rule_text_uk: Вживай my own/your own тощо = «власний/свій», не спільний: my own room, her own business.
rule_short_en: my own = my personal, not shared.
rule_short_uk: my own = мій власний, не спільний.
examples: He wants his own office.
I brought my own coffee.
She started her own company.

rule_text_en: On my own can mean ‘alone’ or ‘without help’, depending on context. By myself usually means ‘alone’.
rule_text_uk: On my own може означати «сам/один» або «без допомоги» (залежить від контексту). By myself зазвичай = «сам/один».
rule_short_en: by myself = alone; on my own = alone/without help.
rule_short_uk: by myself = один; on my own = один/без допомоги.
examples: I went to the cinema by myself.
She lives on her own.
I fixed it on my own.

rule_text_en: Use on your own especially for ‘without help’: I did it on my own. Use by myself to stress ‘alone’.
rule_text_uk: On your own особливо для «без допомоги»: I did it on my own. By myself підкреслює «один/сам».
rule_short_en: on my own = without help (often); by myself = alone.
rule_short_uk: on my own = без допомоги; by myself = один/сам.
examples: He learnt Spanish on his own.
Don’t go by yourself at night.
We built the shelf on our own.

rule_text_en: Use there is/are to say that something exists or is present (There is a café near here).
rule_text_uk: Використовуй there is/are, щоб сказати, що щось існує/є десь (There is a café near here).
examples: There is a problem with the printer.
There are two buses to the centre.
Is there any milk left?

rule_text_en: There can be in other tenses too: there was/were, there has been, there will be, there must be, etc.
rule_text_uk: There вживається і в інших часах: there was/were, there has been, there will be, there must be тощо.
rule_short_en: There + other tenses: was/were, will be, has been.
rule_short_uk: There + інші часи: was/were, will be, has been.
examples: There was a lot of noise last night.
There will be a meeting tomorrow.
There must have been a mistake.

rule_text_en: Use it (not there) for time, weather, distance, and to talk about a situation already known: It’s late. It was windy.
rule_text_uk: Вживай it (не there) для часу, погоди, відстані та відомої ситуації: It’s late. It was windy.
examples: It’s ten o’clock already.
It was cold on the mountain.
It’s a long way to the station.

rule_text_en: Use some in affirmative sentences, and in offers/requests when we expect ‘yes’: I’d like some water. Can I have some help?
rule_text_uk: Вживай some у ствердженнях, а також в пропозиціях/проханнях, коли очікуємо «так»: I’d like some water. Can I have some help?
examples: I bought some fruit.
Can you lend me some money?
Would you like some tea?

rule_text_en: Use any in negative sentences: I don’t have any time. Also after hardly/without: hardly any money.
rule_text_uk: Вживай any у запереченнях: I don’t have any time. Також після hardly/without: hardly any money.
rule_short_en: any in negatives; also after hardly/without.
rule_short_uk: any у запереченнях; також після hardly/without.
examples: We don't have any milk.
She hardly had any sleep.
I left without any explanation.

rule_text_en: In questions we often use any: Do you have any questions? But we can use some if we expect ‘yes’.
rule_text_uk: У питаннях часто any: Do you have any questions? Але some можливе, якщо очікуємо «так».
rule_short_en: Questions: usually any; some if expecting yes.
rule_short_uk: Питання: зазвичай any; some якщо очікуємо «так».
examples: Do you need any help?
Did you buy any bread?
Could I have some more water?

rule_text_en: With someone/something/somewhere and anyone/anything/anywhere, the choice is the same: somebody in affirmatives, anybody in negatives/questions.
rule_text_uk: Із someone/something/somewhere та anyone/anything/anywhere принцип той самий: somebody у ствердженнях, anybody у запереченнях/питаннях.
rule_short_uk: somebody/something vs anybody/anything: ті самі правила.
examples: Somebody is at the door.
I didn't see anybody.
Is there anything I can do?

rule_text_en: Any can mean ‘it doesn’t matter which/what/who’: You can choose any seat. Call me any time.
rule_text_uk: Any може означати «будь‑який/неважливо який»: You can choose any seat. Call me any time.
examples: You can take any book you like.
Any day is fine for me.
Ask anybody in the office.

rule_text_en: No + noun means ‘not any’: no money = not any money. We often prefer no in short answers: No, thanks.
rule_text_uk: No + іменник означає «не жодного»: no money = not any money. У коротких відповідях часто no: No, thanks.
examples: There is no sugar left.
I have no idea.
No problem!

rule_text_en: Use none to replace a noun: How many? None. Use none of + the/this/my etc.: none of the students.
rule_text_uk: None замінює іменник: How many? None. None of + the/this/my тощо: none of the students.
rule_short_en: none = not one; none of + determiner.
examples: How many tickets? None.
None of the rooms were free.
None of my friends called.

rule_text_en: Use nothing/nobody/no one/nowhere with a positive verb (don’t use double negatives): I saw nobody. There’s nowhere to sit.
rule_text_uk: Вживай nothing/nobody/no one/nowhere з стверджувальним дієсловом (без подвійного заперечення): I saw nobody.
examples: Nobody answered.
I found nothing useful.
There was nowhere to park.

rule_text_en: With none of, the verb can be singular or plural depending on the noun: None of the food was… / None of the students were…
rule_text_uk: З none of дієслово може бути в одн. або мн. залежно від іменника: None of the food was… / None of the students were…
rule_short_en: none of + noun: singular/plural verb depends.
rule_short_uk: none of + іменник: одн./мн. залежить від іменника.
examples: None of the information was new.
None of the chairs were comfortable.
None of us were ready.

rule_text_en: Use many/few with countable plurals (many books), and much/little with uncountable nouns (much water).
rule_text_uk: Many/few — з лічильними у множині (many books), much/little — з нелічильними (much water).
examples: How many books do you have?
There isn't much time.
I drank little water.

rule_text_en: In positive sentences we often use a lot of / lots of instead of much/many: I have a lot of work.
rule_text_uk: У ствердженнях часто a lot of/lots of замість much/many: I have a lot of work.
rule_short_en: Positive: often a lot of, not much/many.
rule_short_uk: Ствердження: часто a lot of, не much/many.
examples: We have a lot of visitors.
She spends lots of money.
There’s a lot of traffic.

rule_text_en: A little / a few mean ‘some’ (enough). Little / few (without a) mean ‘not much/not many’ (negative idea).
rule_text_uk: A little/a few = «трохи/кілька» (досить). Little/few (без a) = «майже немає» (негативний відтінок).
rule_short_en: a little/a few = some; little/few = almost none.
rule_short_uk: a little/a few = трохи; little/few = майже немає.
examples: I have a few minutes.
There's little hope.
We made few mistakes.

rule_text_en: Too much/many means ‘more than needed’. Too little/few means ‘not enough’.
rule_text_uk: Too much/many = «занадто багато». Too little/few = «замало/недостатньо».
rule_short_en: too much/many = more than needed; too little/few = not enough.
rule_short_uk: too much/many = більше ніж треба; too little/few = недостатньо.
examples: You talk too much.
There are too many emails.
We have too little time.

rule_text_en: Plenty of means ‘more than enough’. Not much/many is common in short answers: Not much. Not many.
rule_text_uk: Plenty of = «більш ніж достатньо». Not much/many часто у коротких відповідях: Not much. Not many.
rule_short_en: plenty of = more than enough; not much/many for short replies.
rule_short_uk: plenty of = більш ніж достатньо; not much/many у коротких відповідях.
examples: There’s plenty of space.
Not many people came.
Not much has changed.

rule_text_en: All/most/some/no + noun: all cars, most people, some milk, no money. (General meaning, no 'of'.)
rule_text_uk: All/most/some/no + іменник: all cars, most people, some milk, no money (загальне значення, без 'of').
examples: Most people like music.
All children need sleep.
No cars were parked outside.

rule_text_en: Use all of / most of / some of / none of before the/this/that/my etc.: most of the people, some of my friends.
rule_text_uk: All of/most of/some of/none of ставимо перед the/this/that/my тощо: most of the people, some of my friends.
examples: Most of the shops are open.
Some of my friends are abroad.
All of this food is spicy.

rule_text_en: With object pronouns we usually use of: all of us, some of them, most of you. (Not: all us.)
rule_text_uk: З займенниками-об’єктами зазвичай of: all of us, some of them, most of you (не all us).
rule_short_en: Pronouns: all of us / some of them.
rule_short_uk: Займенники: all of us / some of them.
examples: All of us were tired.
Some of them left early.
Most of you know this already.

rule_text_en: None of means ‘not any of’: none of the students, none of them. We can also say not all (= some are not).
rule_text_uk: None of = «жоден/жодне з»: none of the students, none of them. Також not all (= не всі).
rule_short_en: none of = not any of; not all = some not.
rule_short_uk: none of = not any of; not all = деякі ні.
examples: None of the answers were correct.
None of them replied.
Not all students passed.

rule_text_en: Both refers to two things/people together: both cars, both of us. Verb is usually plural: Both are…
rule_text_uk: Both стосується двох разом: both cars, both of us. Дієслово зазвичай у множині: Both are…
rule_short_en: both = the two together; plural verb.
examples: Both answers are correct.
Both of us were tired.
I like both films.

rule_text_en: Either means ‘one of two’ (it doesn’t matter which): Either day is fine. Either of the options works.
rule_text_uk: Either = «один із двох» (неважливо який): Either day is fine. Either of the options works.
examples: You can sit on either side.
Either answer is acceptable.
Either of them can drive.

rule_text_en: Neither means ‘not one and not the other’: Neither answer is correct. Neither of them called.
rule_text_uk: Neither = «ні той, ні інший»: Neither answer is correct. Neither of them called.
rule_short_en: neither = not one nor the other.
examples: Neither plan will work.
Neither of the buses was on time.
I like neither colour.

rule_text_en: Either...or and neither...nor link two alternatives: Either we go now or we stay. Neither tea nor coffee for me.
rule_text_uk: Either...or і neither...nor поєднують альтернативи: Either we go now or we stay. Neither tea nor coffee for me.
examples: Either Anna or Ben will call.
Neither rain nor wind stopped them.
We can either walk or take a taxi.

rule_text_en: All + plural noun means ‘the complete number’: all students. Every + singular means ‘each one’: every student.
rule_text_uk: All + множина = «усі (разом)»: all students. Every + однина = «кожен»: every student.
examples: All students were present.
Every student has an ID card.
I work every day.

rule_text_en: Everybody/everyone/everything = every person/thing. All (of) us/them = the whole group.
rule_text_uk: Everybody/everyone/everything = кожна людина/річ. All (of) us/them = уся група.
rule_short_en: everybody = every person; all of us = the whole group.
rule_short_uk: everybody = кожен; all of us = вся група.
examples: Everybody knows that song.
Everything is ready.
All of us agreed.

rule_text_en: Whole means ‘complete’: the whole day, a whole week. Compare: all day (duration) vs the whole day (complete day).
rule_text_uk: Whole = «цілий/весь»: the whole day, a whole week. Порівняй: all day (тривалість) vs the whole day (цілий день).
rule_short_en: whole = complete; all day vs the whole day.
rule_short_uk: whole = цілий; all day vs the whole day.
examples: I worked all day.
I stayed at home the whole day.
We waited a whole hour.

rule_text_en: We usually say all day/night/week, but the whole morning/afternoon/evening. With of: all of the…, the whole of the…
rule_text_uk: Зазвичай all day/night/week, але the whole morning/afternoon/evening. З of: all of the…, the whole of the…
rule_short_en: Common patterns: all day; the whole morning; all of the…
rule_short_uk: Типові: all day; the whole morning; all of the…
examples: She slept all night.
He studied the whole afternoon.
All of the cake is gone.

rule_text_en: Use each or every to talk about all members of a group. Each focuses on members one by one; every gives a general idea.
rule_text_uk: Використовуйте each або every, коли говорите про всіх у групі. Each підкреслює кожного окремо, а every — загальну ідею.
rule_short_en: each/every = all in a group (focus differs)
examples: Each student has a locker.
I check my email every morning.
Each of the lights was on.
Every seat was taken.

rule_text_en: Use each of + plural noun/pronoun (each of the students / each of them). With every, use every one of, not *every of*.
rule_text_uk: Використовуйте each of + множину (each of the students / each of them). З every вживають every one of, а не *every of*.
examples: Each of my friends lives in a different city.
Every one of these keys is important.
Each of them agreed.
Every one of the rooms was clean.

rule_text_en: Each can go after the noun or at the end: two tickets each / They cost €5 each.
rule_text_uk: Each може стояти після іменника або в кінці: two tickets each / They cost €5 each.
rule_short_en: each can come at the end
examples: The apples are 30 cents each.
We were given a badge each.
They got two days off each.
The coffees cost €3 each.

rule_text_en: Everyone (everybody) means ‘all people’. Every one means ‘each single person/thing’ (two words).
rule_text_uk: Everyone (everybody) означає «усі люди». Every one означає «кожен окремий» (два слова).
rule_short_en: everyone = all people; every one = each single
rule_short_uk: everyone = усі люди; every one = кожен окремий
examples: Everyone knows that street.
Every one of the answers was wrong.
Everyone was invited.
Every one of the candles went out.

rule_text_en: A relative clause tells you which person or thing we mean, or adds information about it.
rule_text_uk: Підрядне означальне речення (relative clause) уточнює, про яку людину/річ ідеться, або додає про неї інформацію.
rule_short_en: Relative clause = extra info about a noun
rule_short_uk: Relative clause = додаткова інформація про іменник
examples: That’s the man who helped me.
This is the book that changed my mind.
I met a woman who works with my sister.

rule_text_en: For people, use who (or that) in defining relative clauses. Don’t repeat he/she/they.
rule_text_uk: Про людей у означальних підрядних зазвичай кажуть who (або that). Не повторюйте he/she/they.
examples: The girl who called you is here.
I like people that make me laugh.
The man who lives upstairs is a pilot.

rule_text_en: For things, use which (or that) in defining relative clauses. Don’t repeat it/they.
rule_text_uk: Про речі в означальних підрядних кажуть which (або that). Не повторюйте it/they.
examples: Where’s the phone which was on the table?
I need a tool that cuts metal.
The movie which we watched was long.

rule_text_en: What means ‘the thing(s) that’. We use what without a noun before it.
rule_text_uk: What означає «те, що / те, що саме». What вживаємо без іменника перед ним.
examples: I don’t understand what you mean.
Tell me what happened.
What she said surprised me.

rule_text_en: If the relative pronoun is the subject of the clause, you must use who/that/which.
rule_text_uk: Якщо відносний займенник є підметом у підрядному, його не можна пропускати: who/that/which потрібні.
examples: The people who live next door are friendly.
I lost the key that opens this door.
It was a song which made me cry.

rule_text_en: If the relative pronoun is the object, you can often leave it out (especially in spoken English).
rule_text_uk: Якщо відносний займенник є додатком, його часто можна опустити (особливо в розмовній мові).
examples: The book (that) I bought is great.
The person (who) you met is my boss.
The film (which) we saw was funny.

rule_text_en: With prepositions, the preposition often goes at the end: the man I spoke to. (Formal: to whom / in which.)
rule_text_uk: З прийменниками прийменник часто стоїть в кінці: the man I spoke to. (Офіційно: to whom / in which.)
examples: This is the chair I sat on.
She’s the colleague I work with.
Is that the hotel you stayed at?

rule_text_en: Use that (not what) after words like everything/all/something. Use what when it means ‘the thing(s) that’.
rule_text_uk: Після everything/all/something вживайте that (не what). What використовують у значенні «те, що».
rule_short_en: everything/all + that; what = the thing that
examples: Everything that he said was true.
I took all (that) I needed.
What you did was brave.

rule_text_en: Whose shows possession in a relative clause: the woman whose car was stolen.
rule_text_uk: Whose показує належність у відносному реченні: the woman whose car was stolen.
examples: I know a man whose sister is a lawyer.
That’s the house whose roof is red.
She met a girl whose phone was broken.

rule_text_en: Whom is the object form for people (formal). In everyday English, we often use who or omit it.
rule_text_uk: Whom — обʼєктна форма для людей (офіційно). У звичайній мові часто вживають who або опускають займенник.
examples: The man whom I saw was angry.
Who did you speak to? (informal)
The person (whom) I called didn’t answer.

rule_text_en: Where can mean ‘in/at/to which’ for places: the restaurant where we met.
rule_text_uk: Where може означати «в/на/куди» для місць: the restaurant where we met.
examples: That’s the park where I learned to ride.
Is this the desk where you work?
We visited the town where my parents met.

rule_text_en: For time/reason words, use that/which/when/why: the day (that) we arrived, the reason (why) I left.
rule_text_uk: Для часу/причини вживають that/which/when/why: the day (that) we arrived, the reason (why) I left.
examples: I remember the day (that) we moved.
Tell me the reason (why) you’re late.
That was the moment when I decided.

rule_text_en: There are two kinds of relative clause: defining (it tells which one) and non-defining (extra information).
rule_text_uk: Є два типи означальних підрядних: визначальні (уточнюють який саме) і невизначальні (додають інформацію).
examples: The man who lives next door is a doctor. (defining)
My brother, who lives in Canada, is visiting. (non-defining)

rule_text_en: Non-defining clauses use commas. You can’t use that, and you can’t omit who/which/whose.
rule_text_uk: Невизначальні підрядні виділяються комами. Не використовують that і не опускають who/which/whose.
rule_short_en: Type 2: commas; no that; no omission
rule_short_uk: Тип 2: коми; без that; не опускати
examples: Sarah, who works with me, is on holiday.
This book, which I bought yesterday, is expensive.
Mr Lee, whose office is upstairs, called.

rule_text_en: Non-defining clauses can refer to a whole clause with which: He missed the train, which annoyed him.
rule_text_uk: У невизначальних підрядних which може посилатися на всю думку: He missed the train, which annoyed him.
rule_short_en: which can refer to the whole clause
examples: He forgot my birthday, which upset me.
We changed the plan, which was a relief.
She apologised, which surprised me.

rule_text_en: In non-defining clauses, a preposition can come before whom/which (formal): to whom, for which.
rule_text_uk: У невизначальних підрядних прийменник може стояти перед whom/which (офіційно): to whom, for which.
examples: Mr Jones, to whom I wrote, replied quickly.
The company, for which she works, is international.
The house, in which they lived, was old.

rule_text_en: Use quantifiers + whom/which: all of whom, none of which, most of which, etc.
rule_text_uk: Вживайте кількісні слова + whom/which: all of whom, none of which, most of which тощо.
examples: Ten students, all of whom passed, celebrated.
She has two cars, neither of which she uses.
We visited three museums, most of which were free.

rule_text_en: Which (not what) can refer to a whole idea: He won again, which amazed us.
rule_text_uk: Which (не what) може стосуватися всієї ситуації: He won again, which amazed us.
rule_short_en: which refers to a whole idea
examples: He cancelled at the last minute, which was annoying.
They moved abroad, which I didn’t expect.
I lost my wallet, which was a disaster.

rule_text_en: Use -ing clauses to describe someone/something doing an action: the woman talking to Tom.
rule_text_uk: Вживайте -ing clauses, щоб описати людину/річ, яка виконує дію: the woman talking to Tom.
examples: The man waiting outside is my uncle.
We saw a dog chasing a cat.
I heard music coming from upstairs.

rule_text_en: Use -ed clauses for passive meaning: the boy injured in the accident, the money stolen.
rule_text_uk: Вживайте -ed clauses для пасивного значення: the boy injured in the accident, the money stolen.
examples: The documents signed yesterday are on my desk.
The bike stolen last week was found.
The cake made by Nina was delicious.

rule_text_en: Use there is/was + -ing/-ed clauses to say what exists or was happening: There were children playing.
rule_text_uk: Використовуйте there is/was + -ing/-ed clauses, щоб сказати, що є/було або що відбувалося: There were children playing.
examples: There was a car parked outside.
Is there anyone waiting?
There were birds singing in the trees.

rule_text_en: -ing adjectives describe something that causes a feeling; -ed adjectives describe how someone feels.
rule_text_uk: -ing прикметники описують те, що викликає відчуття; -ed прикметники описують, як хтось почувається.
examples: The lecture was boring.
I was bored after ten minutes.
It’s an exciting match.
She felt excited.

rule_text_en: Many pairs follow this pattern (interested/interesting, embarrassed/embarrassing, tired/tiring). Choose the form by meaning.
rule_text_uk: Багато пар працюють так само (interested/interesting, embarrassed/embarrassing, tired/tiring). Обирайте форму за значенням.
examples: It was a shocking story.
They were shocked by the news.
The job is tiring.
He’s tired after work.

rule_text_en: Opinion adjectives usually come before fact adjectives: a lovely old house.
rule_text_uk: Оцінні прикметники зазвичай стоять перед фактичними: a lovely old house.
examples: a beautiful large garden
a horrible little mistake
a nice new coat

rule_text_en: Typical order for fact adjectives is: size → age → shape → colour → origin → material → purpose.
rule_text_uk: Типовий порядок фактичних прикметників: розмір → вік → форма → колір → походження → матеріал → призначення.
examples: a small round wooden table
a big old black leather bag
a new Italian sports car

rule_text_en: Use adjectives after be/look/feel/seem etc. Use adverbs to say how you do something: drive carefully.
rule_text_uk: Після be/look/feel/seem тощо вживають прикметники. Прислівники описують, як ви робите дію: drive carefully.
rule_short_en: adjective after be/look; adverb with actions
rule_short_uk: прикм. після be/look; присл. з діями
examples: You look tired.
She spoke politely.
The soup tastes wonderful.
He ran quickly.

rule_text_en: With first/next/last + a number, the number comes after: the first two days, the next few weeks.
rule_text_uk: З first/next/last + числом число стоїть після: the first two days, the next few weeks.
rule_short_en: the first two / the next few / the last three
rule_short_uk: the first two / the next few / the last three
examples: the first three questions
the next ten minutes
the last two chapters

rule_text_en: Many adverbs end in -ly (slowly), but some -ly words are adjectives (friendly, lovely).
rule_text_uk: Багато прислівників закінчуються на -ly (slowly), але деякі -ly слова — прикметники (friendly, lovely).
examples: He spoke quietly.
She smiled happily.
It was a friendly chat.

rule_text_en: Adjectives describe nouns; adverbs describe verbs or whole actions. Some words have different forms: good/well.
rule_text_uk: Прикметники описують іменники; прислівники описують дію. Деякі слова мають різні форми: good/well.
examples: She is a good driver.
She drives well.
The exam was easy.
I did easily the best.

rule_text_en: Use adjectives after be/look/feel/sound etc, but use adverbs after action verbs: speak quietly, work hard.
rule_text_uk: Після be/look/feel/sound тощо — прикметник; після дієслів дії — прислівник: speak quietly, work hard.
examples: I feel happy.
He laughed loudly.
The music sounds terrible.
She sang beautifully.

rule_text_en: Adverbs can modify adjectives/adverbs and past participles: really tired, terribly sorry, badly damaged.
rule_text_uk: Прислівники можуть підсилювати прикметники/прислівники та дієприкметники: really tired, terribly sorry, badly damaged.
examples: I’m extremely sorry.
The building was badly damaged.
She was incredibly kind.

rule_text_en: Use good (adjective) before a noun; use well (adverb) after a verb for how someone does something. Use well with past participles (well-known, well-paid).
rule_text_uk: Good — прикметник (перед іменником); well — прислівник (після дієслова), коли описуємо, як щось роблять. Well також уживається з дієприкметниками: well-known, well-paid.
rule_short_en: good = adjective; well = adverb / past participle
rule_short_uk: good = прикметник; well = прислівник / з дієприкметником
examples: Her writing is good.
She writes well.
a well-known actor
I feel well today.

rule_text_en: Fast, hard and late can be adjectives or adverbs. With work/try, hard means 'with a lot of effort' (work hard).
rule_text_uk: Fast, hard і late можуть бути прикметниками або прислівниками. Hard із work/try означає «з великим зусиллям» (work hard).
rule_short_en: fast/hard/late can be adjective or adverb
rule_short_uk: fast/hard/late можуть бути прикм. або присл.
examples: He’s a fast learner.
He learns fast.
She works hard.
I arrived late.

rule_text_en: Hardly means 'very little / almost not'. It usually goes before the verb (hardly know). Hard and hardly have different meanings.
rule_text_uk: Hardly означає «дуже мало / майже ні». Зазвичай стоїть перед дієсловом (hardly know). Hard і hardly мають різні значення.
examples: I hardly slept.
We hardly know them.
He tried hard.
He hardly tried.

rule_text_en: Late = not on time. Lately = recently. Don’t confuse them (late ≠ lately).
rule_text_uk: Late = «не вчасно». Lately = «останнім часом». Не плутайте: late ≠ lately.
rule_short_en: late = not on time; lately = recently
rule_short_uk: late = не вчасно; lately = останнім часом
examples: Sorry I’m late.
Have you seen her lately?
I stayed up late.
Lately I’ve been busy.

rule_text_en: Use so + adjective/adverb (so cold, so quickly).
rule_text_uk: Вживайте so + прикметник/прислівник: so cold, so quickly.
examples: It’s so noisy here.
She spoke so softly.

rule_text_en: Use such + (a/an) + adjective + noun: such a nice day, such good news.
rule_text_uk: Вживайте such + (a/an) + прикметник + іменник: such a nice day, such good news.
examples: It was such a surprise.
They have such good coffee.

rule_text_en: Use so much/many/little/few + noun: so much work, so many people, so little time, so few seats.
rule_text_uk: Вживайте so much/many/little/few + іменник: so much work, so many people, so little time, so few seats.
examples: We have so much to do.
There were so few tickets.

rule_text_en: So/such can be followed by that to show result: It was so late that we went home. It was such a mess that we stopped.
rule_text_uk: So/such можуть поєднуватися з that, щоб показати наслідок: It was so late that… / It was such a mess that…
examples: It was so hot that we stayed inside.
It was such a long queue that we left.

rule_text_en: Enough usually comes after an adjective/adverb: warm enough, speak loudly enough.
rule_text_uk: Enough зазвичай стоїть після прикметника/прислівника: warm enough, speak loudly enough.
examples: The room isn’t big enough.
You’re not speaking clearly enough.

rule_text_en: Enough comes before a noun: enough money, enough time. Use not enough + noun for lack.
rule_text_uk: Enough стоїть перед іменником: enough money, enough time. Для нестачі: not enough + іменник.
examples: We don’t have enough chairs.
Is there enough sugar?

rule_text_en: Too means 'more than is good/necessary': too hot, too quickly. Use too much/many with nouns.
rule_text_uk: Too означає «забагато / більше, ніж потрібно»: too hot, too quickly. З іменниками: too much/many.
examples: This coffee is too strong.
There are too many emails.

rule_text_en: Use too … to and (not) … enough to: too tired to work; not old enough to drive.
rule_text_uk: Вживайте too … to та (not) … enough to: too tired to work; not old enough to drive.
examples: I was too late to catch the bus.
He isn’t experienced enough to lead it.

rule_text_en: Pretty and fairly mean 'to a moderate degree' and are common in spoken English: pretty tired, fairly easy.
rule_text_uk: Pretty і fairly означають «досить / помірно» і часто вживаються в розмовній мові: pretty tired, fairly easy.
examples: I’m pretty sure.
The test was fairly easy.

rule_text_en: Quite can mean 'fairly' (quite nice) or 'completely' with some adjectives (quite certain). Context matters.
rule_text_uk: Quite може означати «досить» (quite nice) або «повністю» з деякими прикметниками (quite certain). Значення залежить від контексту.
examples: It’s quite good.
I’m quite certain about it.

rule_text_en: Rather often suggests something negative or surprising: rather cold, rather strange. It can also soften criticism.
rule_text_uk: Rather часто має відтінок негативу або несподіванки: rather cold, rather strange. Також може пом’якшувати критику.
examples: It’s rather expensive.
That’s rather odd.

rule_text_en: Rather/quite can be used with a/an: rather a good idea, quite a long time. Word order matters.
rule_text_uk: Rather/quite можна вживати з a/an: rather a good idea, quite a long time. Важливий порядок слів.
examples: It was quite a shock.
It’s rather a mess.

rule_text_en: Form the comparative with -er (cheap→cheaper) or more (expensive→more expensive). Use than to compare.
rule_text_uk: Порівняльний ступінь: -er (cheap→cheaper) або more (expensive→more expensive). Для порівняння вживайте than.
examples: This phone is cheaper than mine.
Today is more humid than yesterday.

rule_text_en: Spelling changes: big→bigger, easy→easier, hot→hotter. Some adjectives are irregular (good→better).
rule_text_uk: Правопис: big→bigger, easy→easier, hot→hotter. Деякі прикметники неправильні (good→better).
examples: A car is bigger than a bike.
This route is easier.

rule_text_en: Use comparative + than, or comparative without than when the comparison is clear from context.
rule_text_uk: Вживайте comparative + than, або comparative без than, якщо порівняння зрозуміле з контексту.
examples: I expected it to be cheaper.
Her new job is better than the old one.

rule_text_en: Use much/far/a lot + comparative for big differences: much better, far more expensive.
rule_text_uk: Використовуйте much/far/a lot + comparative для великої різниці: much better, far more expensive.
examples: This is much easier.
It’s far colder today.

rule_text_en: Use a bit/a little/slightly + comparative for small differences: a bit older, slightly cheaper.
rule_text_uk: Для невеликої різниці: a bit/a little/slightly + comparative: a bit older, slightly cheaper.
examples: He looks a bit tired.
This one is slightly smaller.

rule_text_en: Use any/no + comparative in questions/negatives: any better? no longer. Also: not any bigger.
rule_text_uk: Вживайте any/no + comparative у питаннях і запереченнях: any better? not any bigger. Також: no longer.
examples: Is it any cheaper online?
It’s not any easier now.

rule_text_en: After than you can use object pronoun or clause: than me / than I am. Both are common; choose consistently.
rule_text_uk: Після than можливий займенник-об’єкт або підрядна частина: than me / than I am. Обидва варіанти можливі — дотримуйтеся одного стилю.
examples: She’s taller than me.
She’s taller than I am.

rule_text_en: Use comparative + and + comparative for change (better and better). Use the + comparative, the + comparative (the sooner, the better).
rule_text_uk: Для змін: comparative + and + comparative (better and better). Також: the + comparative, the + comparative (the sooner, the better).
rule_short_en: better and better / the sooner, the better
rule_short_uk: better and better / the sooner, the better
examples: It’s getting colder and colder.
The more you practise, the better you get.

rule_text_en: Use as + adjective/adverb + as to show equality: as tall as, as quickly as.
rule_text_uk: Вживайте as + прикметник/прислівник + as для рівності: as tall as, as quickly as.
examples: My bag is as heavy as yours.
He ran as fast as he could.

rule_text_en: Use not as/so … as for inequality: not as big as, not so expensive as.
rule_text_uk: Для нерівності: not as/so … as: not as big as, not so expensive as.
examples: This room isn’t as bright as the other one.
It’s not so simple as it seems.

rule_text_en: Use as much/many as with nouns: as much time as, as many people as. Also: as little/few as.
rule_text_uk: З іменниками: as much/many as (as much time as, as many people as), також as little/few as.
examples: I don’t have as much time as you.
There weren’t as many guests as expected.

rule_text_en: Use than after comparatives. Don’t use than after as … as.
rule_text_uk: Після порівняльного ступеня вживайте than. Після as … as than не використовується.
examples: She’s older than her brother.
He’s as tall as his dad.

rule_text_en: Form superlatives with -est or most: the cheapest, the most interesting. Use the with superlatives.
rule_text_uk: Найвищий ступінь: -est або most: the cheapest, the most interesting. Зазвичай потрібен the.
examples: This is the smallest box.
It’s the most useful tool.

rule_text_en: Spelling changes: big→the biggest, easy→the easiest. Some are irregular: good→the best, bad→the worst.
rule_text_uk: Правопис: big→the biggest, easy→the easiest. Є неправильні: good→the best, bad→the worst.
examples: That was the best day.
It’s the worst timing.

rule_text_en: Use in/of with superlatives: the tallest in the class; the best of the three options.
rule_text_uk: З найвищим ступенем: in/of — the tallest in the class; the best of the three options.
examples: She’s the fastest in our team.
This is the cheapest of the three.

rule_text_en: Use one of the + superlative + plural noun: one of the most exciting films.
rule_text_uk: Вживайте one of the + найвищий ступінь + множина: one of the most exciting films.
examples: It’s one of the oldest buildings here.
He’s one of the best players.

rule_text_en: Use superlative + ever for lifetime experience: the best meal I’ve ever had.
rule_text_uk: Вживайте superlative + ever для досвіду за все життя: the best meal I’ve ever had.
examples: It was the funniest thing I’ve ever seen.
This is the hardest test I’ve ever done.

rule_text_en: Word order is usually: subject + verb + object. Don’t put the object before the verb in statements.
rule_text_uk: Порядок слів зазвичай: підмет + присудок + додаток. У ствердженнях додаток не ставлять перед дієсловом.
examples: I bought a new phone.
She reads books every day.

rule_text_en: When you have place and time, place usually comes before time: I met her in Kyiv yesterday.
rule_text_uk: Коли є місце й час, зазвичай спершу місце, потім час: I met her in Kyiv yesterday.
examples: We stayed at home all evening.
I saw him at the station this morning.

rule_text_en: With verbs of movement (go, come, travel), place is important and comes after the verb: go to work, travel abroad. Then add time.
rule_text_uk: З дієсловами руху (go, come, travel) місце важливе й стоїть після дієслова: go to work, travel abroad. Потім можна додати час.
examples: She went to the doctor yesterday.
They travelled to Spain last year.

rule_text_en: Adverbs like always/usually/often go before the main verb: I often work from home.
rule_text_uk: Прислівники частоти (always/usually/often) стоять перед основним дієсловом: I often work from home.
examples: I always drink tea.
They usually arrive early.

rule_text_en: With the verb be, adverbs go after be: She is always polite.
rule_text_uk: З дієсловом be прислівник стоїть після be: She is always polite.
examples: He is often busy.
You are never late.

rule_text_en: With auxiliary verbs, adverbs usually go after the first auxiliary: I have never been there.
rule_text_uk: З допоміжними дієсловами прислівник зазвичай після першого допоміжного: I have never been there.
examples: She has already left.
I will probably call later.

rule_text_en: Some adverbs can go at the end, especially manner/time: She spoke quietly. We met again yesterday.
rule_text_uk: Деякі прислівники часто стоять у кінці (особливо способу/часу): She spoke quietly. We met again yesterday.
examples: He drives carefully.
I saw her yesterday.

rule_text_en: Just/already/still usually go in mid position (near the verb/aux): I’m still waiting. I’ve just finished.
rule_text_uk: Just/already/still зазвичай стоять у середині речення (біля дієслова/aux): I’m still waiting. I’ve just finished.
examples: I’m still tired.
She has just arrived.

rule_text_en: Use still for something that continues; it often goes before the main verb (and after be).
rule_text_uk: Still вживаємо, коли дія/ситуація триває; зазвичай воно стоїть перед основним дієсловом (а після be).
rule_short_en: still = continuing; position in the middle
rule_short_uk: still = триває; позиція в середині речення
examples: It’s 10 a.m. and Mia is still asleep.
I still don’t know his surname.
We’re still waiting for the bus.

rule_text_en: Use not … any more/any longer or no longer to say something has stopped or changed.
rule_text_uk: Not … any more/any longer або no longer вживаємо, коли щось припинилося або змінилося.
rule_short_en: not … any more / no longer = not now
rule_short_uk: not … any more / no longer = вже ні
examples: I don’t live there any more.
They no longer work together.
She doesn’t call me any longer.

rule_text_en: Use yet mostly in negatives and questions to mean 'up to now' (expected later).
rule_text_uk: Yet здебільшого вживаємо в запереченнях і питаннях: «досі/ще» (очікується пізніше).
examples: Have you finished yet?
I haven’t sent it yet.
Is he here yet?

rule_text_en: Use already to say something happened earlier than expected; it usually goes in the middle.
rule_text_uk: Already вживаємо, коли щось сталося раніше, ніж очікували; зазвичай стоїть у середині речення.
examples: I’ve already paid the bill.
She’s already left.
Are you already ready?

rule_text_en: Even highlights something surprising or unexpected compared to what you would normally expect.
rule_text_uk: Even підкреслює щось дивне/несподіване порівняно з тим, що зазвичай очікують.
examples: He remembered my birthday, even my middle name.
It’s cold here, even in April.
I couldn’t hear her, even with headphones.

rule_text_en: Even can go before the part you want to emphasise (a noun phrase, time, place, etc.).
rule_text_uk: Even може стояти перед тим, що підкреслюємо (іменник, час, місце тощо).
examples: Even my boss agreed.
She invited everyone, even her ex.
We worked all day, even on Sunday.

rule_text_en: With a verb, even usually goes in the middle: before the main verb, after be/auxiliaries.
rule_text_uk: З дієсловом even зазвичай стоїть у середині: перед основним дієсловом, після be/допоміжних.
rule_short_en: position: be/aux + even; even + main verb
examples: I even forgot your message.
She has even met the CEO.
They were even arguing about it.

rule_text_en: Not even means 'including this (surprising) thing, it didn’t happen / wasn’t true'.
rule_text_uk: Not even означає: «навіть це (несподіване) не сталося/не було правдою».
examples: He didn’t say goodbye, not even to me.
Not even the experts knew the answer.
I wasn’t angry— not even annoyed.

rule_text_en: Use although/though/even though to introduce a contrast clause (it is true, but…).
rule_text_uk: Although/though/even though вводять підрядне речення протиставлення: «хоча…, але…».
examples: Although it was late, we kept working.
I went out, even though I was tired.
Though she apologised, he stayed angry.

rule_text_en: Use in spite of / despite + noun or -ing for contrast (not followed by a full clause without of).
rule_text_uk: In spite of / despite вживаємо з іменником або -ing для протиставлення (не з повним реченням без of).
examples: Despite the rain, we played.
In spite of feeling ill, he went to work.
Despite having little time, she helped.

rule_text_en: You can use despite/in spite of + the fact that + clause, or although/though + clause.
rule_text_uk: Можна: despite/in spite of the fact that + підрядне, або although/though + підрядне.
examples: Despite the fact that it was expensive, I bought it.
Although it was expensive, I bought it.
In spite of the fact that he was new, he led the meeting.

rule_text_en: Though can be used at the end of a sentence (= however) in informal style.
rule_text_uk: Though можна ставити в кінці речення (= however) у розмовному стилі.
examples: I like the city. It’s noisy, though.
We didn’t win. We played well, though.
It was hard. Worth it, though.

rule_text_en: Even though is for real contrast; even if is for an imagined condition.
rule_text_uk: Even though — реальний факт; even if — уявна умова («навіть якщо»).
examples: I stayed, even though I was exhausted.
I’ll go, even if it rains.
Even if you disagree, listen first.

rule_text_en: In case means 'because it is possible this will happen'; you do something as a precaution.
rule_text_uk: In case означає «тому що це може статися»; дія як запобіжний захід.
examples: Take a charger in case your phone dies.
I wrote the address down in case I forgot it.
Keep the receipt in case you need to return it.

rule_text_en: Just in case makes the precaution idea stronger; it often comes at the end.
rule_text_uk: Just in case підсилює ідею запобіжного заходу; часто стоїть наприкінці.
rule_short_en: just in case = for extra safety
rule_short_uk: just in case = на всяк випадок
examples: I’ll bring an umbrella, just in case.
Send me a copy, just in case you lose yours.
I saved the file twice, just in case.

rule_text_en: Use if for a condition/result; use in case for a precaution (not the same meaning).
rule_text_uk: If — умова/результат; in case — запобіжний захід (значення інше).
examples: If it rains, we’ll stay home.
Take a raincoat in case it rains.
Call me if you’re late.

rule_text_en: In case of + noun (or -ing) is used without a clause: in case of fire, in case of delays.
rule_text_uk: In case of + іменник (або -ing) вживається без підрядного: in case of fire, in case of delays.
examples: In case of emergency, press this button.
